column3: 1)	" Well I think this Republican administration has been almost all style
column4: and spectacular
column5: and not substance. We've uh - got a chance tonight to talk about
column6: first of all
column7: leadership
column8: the character of our country
column9: and a vision of the future. In every one of these instances
column10: the Ford administration has failed
column11: and I hope tonight that I and Mr. Ford will have a chance to discuss the reasons for those failures. Our country is not strong anymore; we're not respected anymore. We can only be strong overseas if we're strong at home; and when I became president we'll not only be strong in those areas but also in defense - a defense capability second to none. We've lost in our foreign policy
column12: the character of the American people. We've uh - ignored or excluded the American people and the Congress from participation in the shaping of our foreign policy. It's been one of secrecy and exclusion. In addition to that we've had a chance to became now
column13: contrary to our long-standing beliefs and principles
column14: the arms merchant of the whole world. We've tried to buy success from our enemies
column15: and at the same time we've excluded from the process the normal friendship of our allies. In addition to that we've become fearful to compete with the Soviet Union on an equal basis. We talk about detente. The Soviet Union knows what they want in detente
column16: and they've been getting it. We have not known what we've wanted and we've been out-traded in almost every instance. The other point I wanna make is about our defense. We've got to be a nation blessed with a defense capability that's efficient
column17: tough
column18: capable
column19: well organized
column20: narrowly focused - fighting capability. The ability to fight
column22: is the best way to avoid the chance for
column23: or the requirement to fight. And the last point I wanna make is this: Mr. Ford
column24: Mr. Kissinger have uh - continued on with the policies and failures of Richard Nixon. Even the Republican platform has criticized the lack of leadership in Mr. Ford and they've criticized the foreign policy of this administration. This is one instance where I agree with - with the Republican platform. I might say this in closing
column25: and that is that as far as foreign policy goes
column26: Mr. Kissinger has been the president of this country. Mr. Ford has shown an absence of leadership
column27: and an absence of a grasp of what this country is and what it ought to be. That's got to be changed. And that's one of the major issues in this uh - campaign of 1976.

column1: Governor Carter again is talking in broad generalities. Let me take just one question that he raises - the military strength and capability of the United States. Governor Carter in November of 1975 indicated that he wanted to cut the defense budget by $15 billion. A few months later
column2: he said he wanted to cut the defense budget by eight or nine billion dollars. And more recently
column3: he talks about cutting the defense budget by five to seven billion dollars. There is no way you can be strong militarily and have those kind of reductions in our military uh - appropriation. Now let me just tell you a little story. About uh - late October of 1975
column4: I asked the then Secretary of Defense
column5: Mr. Schlesinger
column6: to tell me what had to be done if we were going to reduce the defense budget by uh - three to five billion dollars. A few days later
column7: Mr. Schlesinger came back and said if we cut the defense budget by three to five billion dollars
column8: we will have to cut military personnel by two hundred and fifty thousand
column9: civilian personnel by a hundred thousand
column10: jobs in America by a hundred thousand. We would have to stretch out our aircraft procurement
column11: we would have to reduce our naval construction program
column12: we would have to reduce the uh - research and development for the Army
column13: the Navy
column14: the Air Force and Marines by 8 percent. We would have to close twenty military bases in the United States immediately. That's the kind of defense program that uh - Mr. Carter wants. Let me tell you this straight from the shoulder. You don't negotiate with Mr. Brezhnev from weakness. And the kind of defense program that Mr. Carter wants will mean a weaker defense and a poor negotiating position.

Even the Republican platform has criticized the lack of leadership in Mr. Ford and they've criticized the foreign policy of this administration. This is one instance where I agree with - with the Republican platform. I might say this in closing
column25: and that is that as far as foreign policy goes
column26: Mr. Kissinger has been the president of this country. Mr. Ford has shown an absence of leadership
column27: and an absence of a grasp of what this country is and what it ought to be. That's got to be changed. And that's one of the major issues in this uh - campaign of 1976.

column1: Governor Carter again is talking in broad generalities. Let me take just one question that he raises - the military strength and capability of the United States. Governor Carter in November of 1975 indicated that he wanted to cut the defense budget by $15 billion. A few months later
column2: he said he wanted to cut the defense budget by eight or nine billion dollars. And more recently
column3: he talks about cutting the defense budget by five to seven billion dollars. There is no way you can be strong militarily and have those kind of reductions in our military uh - appropriation. Now let me just tell you a little story. About uh - late October of 1975
column4: I asked the then Secretary of Defense
column5: Mr. Schlesinger
column6: to tell me what had to be done if we were going to reduce the defense budget by uh - three to five billion dollars. A few days later
column7: Mr. Schlesinger came back and said if we cut the defense budget by three to five billion dollars
column8: we will have to cut military personnel by two hundred and fifty thousand
column9: civilian personnel by a hundred thousand
column10: jobs in America by a hundred thousand. We would have to stretch out our aircraft procurement
column11: we would have to reduce our naval construction program
column12: we would have to reduce the uh - research and development for the Army
column13: the Navy
column14: the Air Force and Marines by 8 percent. We would have to close twenty military bases in the United States immediately. That's the kind of defense program that uh - Mr. Carter wants. Let me tell you this straight from the shoulder. You don't negotiate with Mr. Brezhnev from weakness. And the kind of defense program that Mr. Carter wants will mean a weaker defense and a poor negotiating position.

Let me tell you this straight from the shoulder. You don't negotiate with Mr. Brezhnev from weakness. And the kind of defense program that Mr. Carter wants will mean a weaker defense and a poor negotiating position.

column3: 10)	" I believe that uh - our foreign policy must express the highest standards of morality. And the initiatives that we took in southern Africa are the best examples of what this administration is doing and will continue to do in the next four years. If the United States had not moved when we did in southern Africa
column4: there's no doubt there would have been an acceleration of bloodshed in that tragic part of the world. If we had not taken our initiative
column5: it's very
column6: very possible that uh - the government of Rhodesia would have been overrun and that the Soviet Union and the Cubans would have dominated uh - southern Africa. So the United States
column7: seeking to preserve the principle of self-determination
column8: to eliminate the possibility of bloodshed
column9: to protect the rights of the minority as we insisted upon the rights of the majority
column10: uh - I believe followed the good conscience of the American people in foreign policy. And I believe that we used our skill. Secretary of State Kissinger has done a superb job in working with the black African nations
column11: the so-called front-line nations. He has done a superb job in getting the prime minister of South Africa
column12: Mr. Vorster
column13: to agree that the time had come for a solution to the problem of Rhodesia. Secretary Kissinger
column14: in his meeting with uh - Prime Minister Smith of Rhodesia
column15: was able to convince him that it was in the best interests of whites as well as blacks in Rhodesia to find an answer for a transitional government and then a majority government. This is a perfect example of the kind of leadership that the United States
column16: under this administration
column17: has taken. And I can assure you that this administration will follow that high moral principle in our future efforts in foreign policy
column18: including our efforts in the Middle East where it is vitally important because the Middle East is the crossroads of the world. There've been more disputes in its area where there's more volatility than any other place in the world. But because Arab nations and the Israelis trust the United States
column19: we were able to take the lead in the Sinai II Agreement. And I can assure you that the United States will have the leadership role in moving toward a comprehensive settlement of the Middle Eastern problems
column20: I hope and trust as soon as possible. And we will do it with the highest moral principles.

column1: I would hope that as we move to one area of the world from another - and the United States must not spread itself too thinly - that was one of the problems that helped to create the circumstances in Vietnam - but as we as a nation find that we are asked by the various parties
column2: either one nation against another or individuals within a nation
column3: that the United States will take the leadership and try to resolve the differences. Let me take uh - South Korea as an example. I have personally told President Pack that the United States does not condone the kind of repressive measures that he has taken in that country. But I think in all fairness and equity we have to recognize the problem that South Korea has. On the north they have North Korea with five hundred thousand well-trained
column4: well-equipped troops - they are supported by the People's Republic of China; they are supported by the Soviet Union. South Korea faces a very delicate situation. Now the United States
column5: in this case
column6: this administration
column7: has recommended a year ago and we have reiterated it again this year
column8: that the United States
column9: South Korea
column10: North Korea and the uh - People's Republic of China sit down at a conference table to resolve the problems of the Korean peninsula. This is a leadership role that the United States under this administration is carrying out
column11: and if we do it
column12: and I think the opportunities and the possibilities are getting better
column13: we will have solved many of the internal domestic problems that exist in South Korea at the present time.

column1: I notice that Mr. Ford didn't comment on the uh - prisons in Chile. This is an - a typical example
column3: where this administration overthrew an elected government and helped to establish a military dictatorship. This has not been an ancient history story. Last year under Mr. Ford
column4: of all the Food for Peace that went to South America
column5: 85 percent went to the military dictatorship in Chile. Another point I wanna make is this. He says we have to move from one area of the world to another. That's one of the problems with this administration's so-called shuttle diplomacy. While the secretary of state's in one country
column6: there are almost a hundred and fifty others that are wondering what we're gonna do next
column7: what will be the next secret agreement. We don't have a comprehensive understandable foreign policy that deals with world problems or even regional problems. Another thing that concerned me was what Mr. Ford said about unemployment
column8: that - insinuating that under Johnson and Kennedy that unemployment could only be held down when this country is at war. Karl Marx said that the free enterprise system in a democracy can only continue to exist when they are at war or preparing far war. Karl Marx was the grandfather of Communism. I don't agree with that statement. I hope Mr. Ford doesn't either. He has put pressure on the Congress - and I don't believe Mr. Ford would even deny this - to hold up on nonproliferation legislation until the Congress agreed for an $8 billion program for private industry to start producing enriched uranium. And the last thing I wanna make is this. He talks about peace and I'm thankful for peace. We were peaceful when Mr. Ford went into office. But he and Mr. Kissinger and others tried to start a new Vietnam in Angola
column9: and it was only the outcry of the American people and the Congress when their secret deal was discovered that prevented our involvement in that conflagration which was taking place there.

column15: was able to convince him that it was in the best interests of whites as well as blacks in Rhodesia to find an answer for a transitional government and then a majority government. This is a perfect example of the kind of leadership that the United States
column16: under this administration
column17: has taken. And I can assure you that this administration will follow that high moral principle in our future efforts in foreign policy
column18: including our efforts in the Middle East where it is vitally important because the Middle East is the crossroads of the world. There've been more disputes in its area where there's more volatility than any other place in the world. But because Arab nations and the Israelis trust the United States
column19: we were able to take the lead in the Sinai II Agreement. And I can assure you that the United States will have the leadership role in moving toward a comprehensive settlement of the Middle Eastern problems
column20: I hope and trust as soon as possible. And we will do it with the highest moral principles.

column1: I would hope that as we move to one area of the world from another - and the United States must not spread itself too thinly - that was one of the problems that helped to create the circumstances in Vietnam - but as we as a nation find that we are asked by the various parties
column2: either one nation against another or individuals within a nation
column3: that the United States will take the leadership and try to resolve the differences. Let me take uh - South Korea as an example. I have personally told President Pack that the United States does not condone the kind of repressive measures that he has taken in that country. But I think in all fairness and equity we have to recognize the problem that South Korea has. On the north they have North Korea with five hundred thousand well-trained
column4: well-equipped troops - they are supported by the People's Republic of China; they are supported by the Soviet Union. South Korea faces a very delicate situation. Now the United States
column5: in this case
column6: this administration
column7: has recommended a year ago and we have reiterated it again this year
column8: that the United States
column9: South Korea
column10: North Korea and the uh - People's Republic of China sit down at a conference table to resolve the problems of the Korean peninsula. This is a leadership role that the United States under this administration is carrying out
column11: and if we do it
column12: and I think the opportunities and the possibilities are getting better
column13: we will have solved many of the internal domestic problems that exist in South Korea at the present time.

column1: I notice that Mr. Ford didn't comment on the uh - prisons in Chile. This is an - a typical example
column3: where this administration overthrew an elected government and helped to establish a military dictatorship. This has not been an ancient history story. Last year under Mr. Ford
column4: of all the Food for Peace that went to South America
column5: 85 percent went to the military dictatorship in Chile. Another point I wanna make is this. He says we have to move from one area of the world to another. That's one of the problems with this administration's so-called shuttle diplomacy. While the secretary of state's in one country
column6: there are almost a hundred and fifty others that are wondering what we're gonna do next
column7: what will be the next secret agreement. We don't have a comprehensive understandable foreign policy that deals with world problems or even regional problems. Another thing that concerned me was what Mr. Ford said about unemployment
column8: that - insinuating that under Johnson and Kennedy that unemployment could only be held down when this country is at war. Karl Marx said that the free enterprise system in a democracy can only continue to exist when they are at war or preparing far war. Karl Marx was the grandfather of Communism. I don't agree with that statement. I hope Mr. Ford doesn't either. He has put pressure on the Congress - and I don't believe Mr. Ford would even deny this - to hold up on nonproliferation legislation until the Congress agreed for an $8 billion program for private industry to start producing enriched uranium. And the last thing I wanna make is this. He talks about peace and I'm thankful for peace. We were peaceful when Mr. Ford went into office. But he and Mr. Kissinger and others tried to start a new Vietnam in Angola
column9: and it was only the outcry of the American people and the Congress when their secret deal was discovered that prevented our involvement in that conflagration which was taking place there.

column3: 12)	" The White House did not uh - prevent the release of that report. On July twelfth of this year
column4: we gave full permission for the release of that report. I was very disappointed in the fact that the uh - GAO released that report because I think it interjected political partisan politics at the present time. But let me comment on the report. Somebody who sits in Washington
column5: D.C.
column6: eighteen months after the Mayaguez incident
column7: can be a very good grandstand quarterback. And let me make another observation. This morning
column8: I got a call from the skipper of the Mayaguez. He was furious because he told me that it was the action of me
column9: President Ford
column10: that saved the lives of the crew of the Mayaguez. And I can assure you that if we had not taken the strong and forceful action that we did
column11: we would have been uh - criticized very
column12: very uh - severely for sitting back and not moving. Captain Miller is thankful. The crew is thankful. We did the right thing. It seems to me that those who sit in Washington eighteen months after the incident are not the best judges of the decision-making process that had to be made by the National Security Council and by myself at the time the incident was developing in the Pacific. Let me assure you that we made every possible overture to the People's Republic of China and through them to the Cambodian Government. We made uh - diplomatic uh - protests to the Cambodian government through the United Nations. Every possible diplomatic means was utilized. But at the same time
column13: I had a responsibility
column14: and so did the National Security Coun- Council
column15: to meet the problem at hand. And we handled it responsibly and I think Captain Miller's testimony to that effect is the best evidence.

column1: Well
column2: I'm reluctant to uh comment on the recent report - I haven't read it. I think the American people have only one - uh requirement - that the facts about Mayaguez be given to them accurately and completely. Mr. Ford has been there for eighteen months. He had the facts that were released today immediately after the Mayaguez incident. I understand that the report today is accurate. Mr. Ford has said
column3: I believe
column4: that it was accurate
column5: and that the White House made no attempt to block the issuing of that report. I don't know if that's exactly accurate or not. I understand that both the - the uh - Department of State and the Defense Department have approved the accuracy of today's report
column6: or yesterday's report
column7: and also the National Security Agency. I don't know what was right
column8: or what was wrong
column9: or what was done. The only thing I believe is that whatever the - the knowledge was that Mr. Ford had should have been given to the American people eighteen months ago
column10: immediately after the Mayaguez uh - incident occurred. This is uh - what the American people want. When something happens that endangers our security
column11: or when something happens that threatens our stature in the world
column12: or when American people are endangered by the actions of a foreign country
column13: uh - just forty uh sailors on the Mayaguez
column14: we obviously have to move aggressively and quickly to rescue them. But then after the immediate action is taken
column15: I believe the president has an obligation to tell the American people the truth and not wait eighteen months later for the report to be issued.

It seems to me that those who sit in Washington eighteen months after the incident are not the best judges of the decision-making process that had to be made by the National Security Council and by myself at the time the incident was developing in the Pacific. Let me assure you that we made every possible overture to the People's Republic of China and through them to the Cambodian Government. We made uh - diplomatic uh - protests to the Cambodian government through the United Nations. Every possible diplomatic means was utilized. But at the same time
column13: I had a responsibility
column14: and so did the National Security Coun- Council
column15: to meet the problem at hand. And we handled it responsibly and I think Captain Miller's testimony to that effect is the best evidence.

column1: Well
column2: I'm reluctant to uh comment on the recent report - I haven't read it. I think the American people have only one - uh requirement - that the facts about Mayaguez be given to them accurately and completely. Mr. Ford has been there for eighteen months. He had the facts that were released today immediately after the Mayaguez incident. I understand that the report today is accurate. Mr. Ford has said
column3: I believe
column4: that it was accurate
column5: and that the White House made no attempt to block the issuing of that report. I don't know if that's exactly accurate or not. I understand that both the - the uh - Department of State and the Defense Department have approved the accuracy of today's report
column6: or yesterday's report
column7: and also the National Security Agency. I don't know what was right
column8: or what was wrong
column9: or what was done. The only thing I believe is that whatever the - the knowledge was that Mr. Ford had should have been given to the American people eighteen months ago
column10: immediately after the Mayaguez uh - incident occurred. This is uh - what the American people want. When something happens that endangers our security
column11: or when something happens that threatens our stature in the world
column12: or when American people are endangered by the actions of a foreign country
column13: uh - just forty uh sailors on the Mayaguez
column14: we obviously have to move aggressively and quickly to rescue them. But then after the immediate action is taken
column15: I believe the president has an obligation to tell the American people the truth and not wait eighteen months later for the report to be issued.

column3: 13)	" I believe that the boycott of American businesses by the Arab countries because those businesses trade with Israel or because they have American Jews who are owners or directors in the company is an absolute disgrace. This is the first time that I've - remember in the history of our country when we've let a foreign country circumvent or change our Bill of Rights. I'll do everything I can as president to stop the boycott of American businesses by the Arab countries. It's not a matter of diplomacy or trade with me. It's a matter of morality. And I don't believe that Arab countries will pursue it when we have a strong president who will protect the integrity of our country
column4: the commitment of our Constitution and Bill of Rights and protect people in this country who happen to be Jews. It may later be Catholics; it may be - later be Baptists who are threatened by some foreign country. But we ought to stand staunch. And I think it's a disgrace that so far Mr. Ford's administration has blocked the passage of legislation that would've revealed by law every instance of the boycott and it would've prevented the boycott from continuing.

column1: Again Governor Carter is inaccurate. The Arab boycott action was first taken in 1952. And in November of 1975 I was the first president to order the executive branch to take action
column3: through the Department of Commerce and other cabinet departments
column4: to make certain that no American businessman or business organization should discriminate against Jews because of an Arab boycott. And I might add that uh - my administration - and I'm very proud of it - is the first administration that has taken an antitrust action against companies in this country that have allegedly cooperated with the Arab boycott. Just on Monday of this week I signed a tax bill that included an amendment that would prevent companies in the United States from taking a tax deduction if they have in any way whatsoever cooperated with the Arab boycott. And last week when we were trying to get the Export Administration Act through the Congress - necessary legislation - my administration went to Capitol Hill and tried to convince the House and the Senate that we should have an amendment on that legislation which would take strong and effective action against those who uh - participate or cooperate with the Arab uh boycott. One other point. Because the Congress failed to act
column5: I am going to announce tomorrow that the Department of Commerce will disclose those companies that have uh - participated in the Arab boycott. This is something that we can do; the Congress failed to do it
column6: and we intend to do it.

column1: Again Governor Carter is inaccurate. The Arab boycott action was first taken in 1952. And in November of 1975 I was the first president to order the executive branch to take action
column3: through the Department of Commerce and other cabinet departments
column4: to make certain that no American businessman or business organization should discriminate against Jews because of an Arab boycott. column3: 14)	" Let me restate uh - our policy. As long as Vietnam
column4: North Vietnam
column5: does not give us a full and complete accounting of our missing in action
column6: I will never uh - go along with the admission of Vietnam to the United Nations. If they do give us a bona fide
column7: complete uh - accounting of the eight hundred MIA's
column8: then I believe that the United States should begin negotiations for the uh - admission of Vietnam to the United Nations. But not until they have given us the full accounting of our MIAs.

column1: One of the uh - most embarrassing uh - failures of the Ford administration
column2: and one that touches specifically on human rights
column3: is his refusal to appoint a presidential commission to go to Vietnam
column4: to go to Laos
column5: to go to Cambodia and try to trade for the release of information about those who are missing in action in those wars. This is what the families of MIAs want. So far
column6: Mr. Ford has not done it. We've had several fragmentary efforts by members of the Congress and by - by private citizens. Several months ago the Vietnam government said
column7: ""We are ready to sit down and negotiate for release of information on MIAs. So far
column8: Mr. Ford has not responded. I would never normalize relationships with Vietnam
column9: nor permit them to join the United Nations until they've taken this action. But that's not enough. We need to have an active and aggressive action on the part of the president
column10: the leader of his country
column11: to seek out every possible way to get that information which has kept the MIA families in despair and doubt
column12: and Mr. Ford has just not done it.

column3: 15)	" The purpose of this debate and the outcome of the election will determine three basic things: Leadership
column4: upholding the principles of our country
column5: and proper priorities and commitments for the future. This election will also determine what kind of world we leave our children. Will it be a nightmare world threatened with the proliferation of atomic bombs
column6: not just in five major countries but dozens of smaller countries that have been permitted to develop atomic weapons because of a failure of our top leadership to stop proliferation? Will we have a world of hunger and - and hatred
column7: and will we be living in an armed camp stripped of our friendship and allies hiding behind a tight defense that's been drawn in around us because we are fearful of the outside world? Will we have a government of secrecy that excludes the American people from participation in making basic decisions and therefore covers up mistakes and makes it possible for our government - our government - to depart from the principles of our Constitution and Bill of Rights? Or will we have a world of peace with the threat of atomic weapons eliminated
column8: with full trade
column9: with our people at work
column10: inflation controlled
column11: openness in government
column12: our people proud once again
column13: Congress
column14: citizens
column15: president
column16: secretary of state working in harmony and unity toward a common future? Or world where people have enough to eat and a world where we care about those who don't? Can we become a breadbasket of the world instead of the arms merchant of the world? I believe we can and we ought to. Now we've been hurt in recent years in this country. In the aftermath of Vietnam
column17: Cambodia
column18: Chile
column19: Pakistan
column20: Angola
column22: CIA
column23: we've been hurt. Our people feel that we've lost something precious. That's not necessary. I wanna see our nation - return to a posture and an image and a standard to make us proud once again. I remember the world with NATO
column24: and the world of Point Four
column25: and the world of the Marshall Plan
column26: and the world of the Peace Corps. Why can't we have that once again? We ought to be a beacon for nations who search for peace and who search for freedom
column27: who search for individual liberty
column28: who search for basic human rights. We haven't been lately. We can be once again. We'll never have that world leadership until we are strong at home
column29: and we can have that strength if we return to the basic principles. It ought not to be a strength of bombast and threats. It ought to be a quiet strength based on the integrity of our people
column30: the vision of the Constitution
column31: an in- innate strong will and purpose that God's given us in the greatest nation on earth - the United States.

column1: As we have seen tonight
column2: foreign policy and defense policy are difficult and complex issues. We can debate methods
column3: we can debate one decision or another
column4: but there are two uh things which cannot be debated - experience and results. In the last two years
column5: I have made policy decisions involving - long-range difficulties and policies and made day-to-day judgments not only as president of the United States but as the leader of the free world What is the result of that leadership? America is strong. America is free. America is respected. Not a single young American today is fighting or dying on any foreign battlefield. America is at peace and with freedom. Thank you
column6: and good night.

column3: 2)	" I don't believe we should move to a cold-war relationship. I think it's in the best interest of the United States
column4: and the world as a whole that the United States negotiate rather than go back to the cold-war relationship with the Soviet Union. I don't uh - look at the picture as bleakly as you have indicated in your question
column5: Mr. Trewhitt. I believe that the United States ha- had many successes in recent years
column6: in recent months
column7: as far as the Communist movement is concerned. We have been successful in Portugal
column8: where a year ago it looked like there was a very great possibility that the uh - Communists would take over in Portugal. It didn't happen. We have a democracy in Portugal today. A few uh - months ago
column9: or I should say
column10: maybe two years ago
column11: the Soviet Union looked like they had continued strength in the Middle East. Today
column12: according to Prime Minister Rabin
column13: the Soviet Union is weaker in the Middle East than they have been in many
column14: many years. The facts are
column15: there - the Soviet Union relationship with Egypt is uh - at a low level. The Soviet Union relationship with Syria is at a very low point. The United States today
column16: according to Prime Minister Rabin of Israel
column17: is a- at a peak in its uh - influence and power in the Middle East. But let's turn for a minute to the uhh - southern African operations that are now going on. The United States of America took the initiative in southern Africa. We wanted to end the bloodshed in southern Africa. We wanted to have the right of self-determination in southern Africa. We wanted to have majority rule with the full protection of the rights of the minority. We wanted to preserve human dignity in southern Africa. We have taken the initiative
column18: and in southern Africa today the United States is trusted by the black front-line nations and black Africa. The United States is trusted by other elements in southern Africa. The United States foreign policy under this administration has been one of progress and success. And I believe that instead of talking about Soviet progress
column19: we can talk about American successes. And may I make an observation - part of the question you asked
column20: Mr. Trewhitt? I don't believe that it's in the best interest of the United States and the NATO nations to have a Communist government in NATO. Mr. Carter has indicated he would look with sympathy to a Communist government in NATO. I think that would destroy the integrity and the strength of NATO
column21: and I am totally opposed to it.

column1: Well
column3: unfortunately
column4: has just made a statement that's not true. I have never advocated a Communist government for Italy. That would obviously be a ridiculous thing for anyone to do who wanted to be president of this country. I think that this is uh - an instance of uh - deliberate distortion
column5: and this has occurred also in the question about defense. As a matter of fact
column6: uh - I've never advocated any cut of $15 billion in our defense budget. As a matter of fact
column7: Mr. Ford has made a political football out of the defense budget. About a year ago he cut the Pentagon budget six point eight billion dollars. After he fired James Schlesinger
column8: the political heat got so great that he added back about $3 billion. When Ronald Reagan won the Texas primary election
column9: Mr. Ford added back another one and a half billion dollars. Immediately before the Kansas City convention
column10: he added back another one point eight billion dollars in the defense budget. And his own uh - Office of Management and Budget testified that he had a $3 billion cut insurance added to the defense budget - defense budget under the pressure from the Pentagon. Obviously
column11: this is another indication of trying to use the defense budget for political purposes
column12: which he's trying to do tonight. Now
column13: we went into south Africa late
column14: after Great Britain
column15: Rhodesia
column16: the black nations had been trying to solve this problem for many
column17: many years. We didn't go in until right before the election
column18: similar to what was taking place in 1972
column19: when Mr. Kissinger announced peace is at hand just before the election at that time. And we have weakened our position in NATO because the other countries in Europe supported the democ- democratic forces in Portugal long before we did; we stuck to the Portugal dictatorships much longer than other democracies did in this world.

column6: in recent months

column8: where a year ago it looked like there was a very great possibility that the uh - Communists would take over in Portugal. It didn't happen. We have a democracy in Portugal today. A few uh - months ago
column9: or I should say
column10: maybe two years ago
column11: the Soviet Union looked like they had continued strength in the Middle East. Today
column12: according to Prime Minister Rabin
column13: the Soviet Union is weaker in the Middle East than they have been in many
column14: many years. The facts are

column16: according to Prime Minister Rabin of Israel
column17: is a- at a peak in its uh - influence and power in the Middle East. But let's turn for a minute to the uhh - southern African operations that are now going on. The United States of America took the initiative in southern Africa. We wanted to end the bloodshed in southern Africa. We wanted to have the right of self-determination in southern Africa. We wanted to have majority rule with the full protection of the rights of the minority. We wanted to preserve human dignity in southern Africa. We have taken the initiative
column18: and in southern Africa today the United States is trusted by the black front-line nations and black Africa. The United States is trusted by other elements in southern Africa. column19: we can talk about American successes. And may I make an observation - part of the question you asked
column20: Mr. Trewhitt? I don't believe that it's in the best interest of the United States and the NATO nations to have a Communist government in NATO. Mr. Carter has indicated he would look with sympathy to a Communist government in NATO. I think that would destroy the integrity and the strength of NATO
column21: and I am totally opposed to it.

column1: Well
column3: unfortunately
column4: has just made a statement that's not true. I have never advocated a Communist government for Italy. That would obviously be a ridiculous thing for anyone to do who wanted to be president of this country. I think that this is uh - an instance of uh - deliberate distortion
column5: and this has occurred also in the question about defense. As a matter of fact
column6: uh - I've never advocated any cut of $15 billion in our defense budget. As a matter of fact
column7: Mr. Ford has made a political football out of the defense budget. About a year ago he cut the Pentagon budget six point eight billion dollars. After he fired James Schlesinger
column8: the political heat got so great that he added back about $3 billion. When Ronald Reagan won the Texas primary election
column9: Mr. Ford added back another one and a half billion dollars. Immediately before the Kansas City convention
column10: he added back another one point eight billion dollars in the defense budget. And his own uh - Office of Management and Budget testified that he had a $3 billion cut insurance added to the defense budget - defense budget under the pressure from the Pentagon. Obviously
column11: this is another indication of trying to use the defense budget for political purposes
column12: which he's trying to do tonight. Now
column13: we went into south Africa late
column14: after Great Britain
column15: Rhodesia
column16: the black nations had been trying to solve this problem for many
column17: many years. We didn't go in until right before the election
column18: similar to what was taking place in 1972
column19: when Mr. Kissinger announced peace is at hand just before the election at that time. And we have weakened our position in NATO because the other countries in Europe supported the democ- democratic forces in Portugal long before we did; we stuck to the Portugal dictatorships much longer than other democracies did in this world.

column5: Mr. Trewhitt. I believe that the United States ha- had many successes in recent years
column6: in recent months
column7: as far as the Communist movement is concerned. We have been successful in Portugal
column8: where a year ago it looked like there was a very great possibility that the uh - Communists would take over in Portugal. It didn't happen. We have a democracy in Portugal today. A few uh - months ago
column9: or I should say
column10: maybe two years ago
column11: the Soviet Union looked like they had continued strength in the Middle East. Today
column12: according to Prime Minister Rabin
column13: the Soviet Union is weaker in the Middle East than they have been in many
column14: many years. The facts are
column15: there - the Soviet Union relationship with Egypt is uh - at a low level. The Soviet Union relationship with Syria is at a very low point. The United States today
column16: according to Prime Minister Rabin of Israel
column17: is a- at a peak in its uh - influence and power in the Middle East. But let's turn for a minute to the uhh - southern African operations that are now going on. The United States of America took the initiative in southern Africa. We wanted to end the bloodshed in southern Africa. We wanted to have the right of self-determination in southern Africa. We wanted to have majority rule with the full protection of the rights of the minority. We wanted to preserve human dignity in southern Africa. We have taken the initiative
column18: and in southern Africa today the United States is trusted by the black front-line nations and black Africa. The United States is trusted by other elements in southern Africa. column21: and I am totally opposed to it.

column1: Well
column3: unfortunately
column4: has just made a statement that's not true. I have never advocated a Communist government for Italy. That would obviously be a ridiculous thing for anyone to do who wanted to be president of this country. I think that this is uh - an instance of uh - deliberate distortion
column5: and this has occurred also in the question about defense. As a matter of fact
column6: uh - I've never advocated any cut of $15 billion in our defense budget. As a matter of fact
column7: Mr. Ford has made a political football out of the defense budget. About a year ago he cut the Pentagon budget six point eight billion dollars. After he fired James Schlesinger
column8: the political heat got so great that he added back about $3 billion. When Ronald Reagan won the Texas primary election
column9: Mr. Ford added back another one and a half billion dollars. Immediately before the Kansas City convention
column10: he added back another one point eight billion dollars in the defense budget. And his own uh - Office of Management and Budget testified that he had a $3 billion cut insurance added to the defense budget - defense budget under the pressure from the Pentagon. Obviously
column11: this is another indication of trying to use the defense budget for political purposes
column12: which he's trying to do tonight. Now
column13: we went into south Africa late

column15: Rhodesia

column19: when Mr. Kissinger announced peace is at hand just before the election at that time. And we have weakened our position in NATO because the other countries in Europe supported the democ- democratic forces in Portugal long before we did; we stuck to the Portugal dictatorships much longer than other democracies did in this world.

column3: 3)	" Well
column4: I'm not gonna name my cabinet before I get elected. I've got a little ways to go before I start doing that. But I have uh - an adequate background
column5: I believe. I am a graduate of the U.S. Naval Academy
column6: the first military graduate since uh - Eisenhower. I've served as the Governor of Georgia and have traveled extensively in foreign countries and South America
column7: Central America
column8: Europe
column9: the Middle East and in Japan. I've traveled the last twenty-one months among the people of this country. I've talked to them and I've listened. And I've seen at first hand
column10: in a very vivid way
column11: the deep hurt that's come to this country in the aftermath of Vietnam and Cambodia
column12: Chile
column13: and Pakistan
column14: and Angola
column15: and Watergate
column16: CIA revelations. What we were formerly so proud of - the strength of our country
column17: its uh - moral integrity
column18: the representation in foreign affairs of what our people are
column19: what our Constitution stands for
column20: has been gone. And in the secrecy that has surrounded our foreign policy in the last few years
column22: the Congress have been excluded. I believe I know what this country ought to be. I've uh - been one who's loved my nation as many Americans do
column23: and I believe that there's no limit placed on what we can be in the future
column24: if we can harness the tremendous resources - militarily
column25: economically
column26: and the stature of our people
column27: the meaning of the Constitution
column28: in the future. Every time we've made a serious mistake in foreign affairs
column29: it's been because the American people have been excluded from the process. If we can just tap the intelligence and ability
column30: the sound common sense and the good judgment of the American people
column31: we can once again have a foreign policy to make us proud instead of ashamed. And I'm not gonna exclude the American people from that process in the future
column32: as Mr. Ford and Kissinger have done. This is what it takes to have a sound foreign policy strong at home
column33: strong defense
column34: permanent commitments
column35: not betray the principles of our country
column36: and involve the American people and the Congress in the shaping of our foreign policy. Every time Mr. Ford speaks from a position of secrecy in negotiations
column37: in secret - in secret treaties that've been uh - pursued and achieved
column38: in supporting dictatorships
column39: in ignoring human rights
column40: we are weak and the rest of the world knows it. So these are the ways that we can restore the strength of our country
column41: and they don't require long experience in foreign policy. Nobody has that except a president who has served a long time or a secretary of state. But my background
column42: my experience
column43: my knowledge of the people of this country
column44: my commitment to our principles that don't change - those are the best bases to correct the horrible mistakes of this administration and restore our own country to a position of leadership in the world.

column1: First of all
column2: I would quit conducting the decision-making process in secret
column3: as has been a characteristic of Mr. Kissinger and Mr. Ford. In many instances we've made agreements
column4: like in Vietnam
column5: uh - that have uh - been revealed later on to our uh - embarrassment. Recently Ian Smith
column6: the uh - president of uh - Rhodesia
column7: announced that he had unequivocal commitments from Mr. Kissinger that he could not reveal. The American people don't know what those commitments are. We've seen uh - in the past the destruction of elected governments
column8: like in Chile
column9: and the strong support of military dictatorship there. These kinds of things have hurt us very much. I would restore the concept of the fireside chat
column10: which was an integral part of the administration of Franklin Roosevelt. And I would also restore the involvement of the Congress. When Harry Truman was president he was not afraid to have a strong secretary of defense. Dean Acheson
column11: George Marshall were strong secretaries of uh - state - excuse me - state. But he also made sure that there was a bipartisan support. The members of Congress
column12: Arthur Vandenberg
column13: Walter George
column14: were part of the process
column15: and before our nation made a secret agreement
column16: or before we made a bluffing statement
column17: we were sure that we had the backing not only of the president and the secretary of state
column18: but also of the Congress and the people. This is a responsibility of the president. And I think it's very damaging to our country for Mr. Ford to have turned over this responsibility to the secretary of state.

column1: Governor Carter again contradicts himself. He complains about secrecy and yet he is quoted as saying that in the attempt to find a solution in the Middle East that he would hold unpublicized meetings with the Soviet Union - I presume for the purpose of an - imposing a settlement on Israel and the Arab nations. But let me talk just a minute about what we've done to avoid secrecy in the Ford administration. After the United States took the initiative in working with Israel and with Egypt and achieving the Sinai II agreement - and I'm proud to say that not a single Egyptian or Israeli soldier has lost his life since the signing of the Sinai agreement. But at the time that uh - I submitted the Sinai agreement to the Congress of the United States
column2: I submitted every single document that was applicable to the Sinai II agreement. It was the most complete documentation by any president of any agreement signed by a president on behalf of the United States. Now as far as meeting with the Congress is concerned
column3: during the twenty-four months that I've been the president of the United States I have averaged better than one meeting a month with responsible groups or committees of the Congress - both House and Senate. The secretary of state has appeared in the several years that he's been the secretary before eighty different uh - committee hearings in the House and in the Senate. The secretary of state has made better than fifty speeches all over the United States explaining American foreign policy. I have made myself at least ten uh - speeches in various parts of the country where I have discussed with the American people defense and foreign policy.

column3: 3)	" Well
column4: I'm not gonna name my cabinet before I get elected. I've got a little ways to go before I start doing that. But I have uh - an adequate background
column5: I believe. I am a graduate of the U.S. Naval Academy
column6: the first military graduate since uh - Eisenhower. I've served as the Governor of Georgia and have traveled extensively in foreign countries and South America
column7: Central America
column8: Europe
column9: the Middle East and in Japan. I've traveled the last twenty-one months among the people of this country. I've talked to them and I've listened. And I've seen at first hand
column10: in a very vivid way
column11: the deep hurt that's come to this country in the aftermath of Vietnam and Cambodia
column12: Chile
column13: and Pakistan
column14: and Angola
column15: and Watergate
column16: CIA revelations. What we were formerly so proud of - the strength of our country
column17: its uh - moral integrity
column18: the representation in foreign affairs of what our people are
column19: what our Constitution stands for
column20: has been gone. And in the secrecy that has surrounded our foreign policy in the last few years
column22: the Congress have been excluded. I believe I know what this country ought to be. I've uh - been one who's loved my nation as many Americans do
column23: and I believe that there's no limit placed on what we can be in the future
column24: if we can harness the tremendous resources - militarily
column25: economically
column26: and the stature of our people
column27: the meaning of the Constitution
column28: in the future. Every time we've made a serious mistake in foreign affairs
column29: it's been because the American people have been excluded from the process. If we can just tap the intelligence and ability
column30: the sound common sense and the good judgment of the American people
column31: we can once again have a foreign policy to make us proud instead of ashamed. And I'm not gonna exclude the American people from that process in the future
column32: as Mr. Ford and Kissinger have done. This is what it takes to have a sound foreign policy strong at home
column33: strong defense
column34: permanent commitments
column35: not betray the principles of our country
column36: and involve the American people and the Congress in the shaping of our foreign policy. Every time Mr. Ford speaks from a position of secrecy in negotiations
column37: in secret - in secret treaties that've been uh - pursued and achieved
column38: in supporting dictatorships
column39: in ignoring human rights
column40: we are weak and the rest of the world knows it. So these are the ways that we can restore the strength of our country
column41: and they don't require long experience in foreign policy. Nobody has that except a president who has served a long time or a secretary of state. But my background
column42: my experience
column43: my knowledge of the people of this country
column44: my commitment to our principles that don't change - those are the best bases to correct the horrible mistakes of this administration and restore our own country to a position of leadership in the world.

column1: First of all
column2: I would quit conducting the decision-making process in secret
column3: as has been a characteristic of Mr. Kissinger and Mr. Ford. In many instances we've made agreements
column4: like in Vietnam
column5: uh - that have uh - been revealed later on to our uh - embarrassment. Recently Ian Smith
column6: the uh - president of uh - Rhodesia
column7: announced that he had unequivocal commitments from Mr. Kissinger that he could not reveal. The American people don't know what those commitments are. We've seen uh - in the past the destruction of elected governments
column8: like in Chile
column9: and the strong support of military dictatorship there. These kinds of things have hurt us very much. I would restore the concept of the fireside chat
column10: which was an integral part of the administration of Franklin Roosevelt. And I would also restore the involvement of the Congress. When Harry Truman was president he was not afraid to have a strong secretary of defense. Dean Acheson
column11: George Marshall were strong secretaries of uh - state - excuse me - state. But he also made sure that there was a bipartisan support. The members of Congress
column12: Arthur Vandenberg
column13: Walter George
column14: were part of the process
column15: and before our nation made a secret agreement
column16: or before we made a bluffing statement
column17: we were sure that we had the backing not only of the president and the secretary of state
column18: but also of the Congress and the people. This is a responsibility of the president. And I think it's very damaging to our country for Mr. Ford to have turned over this responsibility to the secretary of state.

column1: Governor Carter again contradicts himself. He complains about secrecy and yet he is quoted as saying that in the attempt to find a solution in the Middle East that he would hold unpublicized meetings with the Soviet Union - I presume for the purpose of an - imposing a settlement on Israel and the Arab nations. But let me talk just a minute about what we've done to avoid secrecy in the Ford administration. After the United States took the initiative in working with Israel and with Egypt and achieving the Sinai II agreement - and I'm proud to say that not a single Egyptian or Israeli soldier has lost his life since the signing of the Sinai agreement. But at the time that uh - I submitted the Sinai agreement to the Congress of the United States
column2: I submitted every single document that was applicable to the Sinai II agreement. It was the most complete documentation by any president of any agreement signed by a president on behalf of the United States. Now as far as meeting with the Congress is concerned
column3: during the twenty-four months that I've been the president of the United States I have averaged better than one meeting a month with responsible groups or committees of the Congress - both House and Senate. The secretary of state has appeared in the several years that he's been the secretary before eighty different uh - committee hearings in the House and in the Senate. The secretary of state has made better than fifty speeches all over the United States explaining American foreign policy. I have made myself at least ten uh - speeches in various parts of the country where I have discussed with the American people defense and foreign policy.

column24: if we can harness the tremendous resources - militarily
column25: economically
column26: and the stature of our people
column27: the meaning of the Constitution
column28: in the future. Every time we've made a serious mistake in foreign affairs
column29: it's been because the American people have been excluded from the process. If we can just tap the intelligence and ability
column30: the sound common sense and the good judgment of the American people
column31: we can once again have a foreign policy to make us proud instead of ashamed. And I'm not gonna exclude the American people from that process in the future
column32: as Mr. Ford and Kissinger have done. This is what it takes to have a sound foreign policy strong at home
column33: strong defense
column34: permanent commitments
column35: not betray the principles of our country
column36: and involve the American people and the Congress in the shaping of our foreign policy. Every time Mr. Ford speaks from a position of secrecy in negotiations
column37: in secret - in secret treaties that've been uh - pursued and achieved
column38: in supporting dictatorships
column39: in ignoring human rights
column40: we are weak and the rest of the world knows it. So these are the ways that we can restore the strength of our country
column41: and they don't require long experience in foreign policy. Nobody has that except a president who has served a long time or a secretary of state. But my background
column42: my experience
column43: my knowledge of the people of this country
column44: my commitment to our principles that don't change - those are the best bases to correct the horrible mistakes of this administration and restore our own country to a position of leadership in the world.

column1: First of all
column2: I would quit conducting the decision-making process in secret
column3: as has been a characteristic of Mr. Kissinger and Mr. Ford. In many instances we've made agreements
column4: like in Vietnam
column5: uh - that have uh - been revealed later on to our uh - embarrassment. Recently Ian Smith
column6: the uh - president of uh - Rhodesia
column7: announced that he had unequivocal commitments from Mr. Kissinger that he could not reveal. The American people don't know what those commitments are. We've seen uh - in the past the destruction of elected governments
column8: like in Chile
column9: and the strong support of military dictatorship there. These kinds of things have hurt us very much. I would restore the concept of the fireside chat
column10: which was an integral part of the administration of Franklin Roosevelt. And I would also restore the involvement of the Congress. When Harry Truman was president he was not afraid to have a strong secretary of defense. Dean Acheson
column11: George Marshall were strong secretaries of uh - state - excuse me - state. But he also made sure that there was a bipartisan support. The members of Congress
column12: Arthur Vandenberg
column13: Walter George
column14: were part of the process
column15: and before our nation made a secret agreement
column16: or before we made a bluffing statement
column17: we were sure that we had the backing not only of the president and the secretary of state
column18: but also of the Congress and the people. This is a responsibility of the president. And I think it's very damaging to our country for Mr. Ford to have turned over this responsibility to the secretary of state.

column1: Governor Carter again contradicts himself. He complains about secrecy and yet he is quoted as saying that in the attempt to find a solution in the Middle East that he would hold unpublicized meetings with the Soviet Union - I presume for the purpose of an - imposing a settlement on Israel and the Arab nations. But let me talk just a minute about what we've done to avoid secrecy in the Ford administration. After the United States took the initiative in working with Israel and with Egypt and achieving the Sinai II agreement - and I'm proud to say that not a single Egyptian or Israeli soldier has lost his life since the signing of the Sinai agreement. But at the time that uh - I submitted the Sinai agreement to the Congress of the United States
column2: I submitted every single document that was applicable to the Sinai II agreement. It was the most complete documentation by any president of any agreement signed by a president on behalf of the United States. Now as far as meeting with the Congress is concerned
column3: during the twenty-four months that I've been the president of the United States I have averaged better than one meeting a month with responsible groups or committees of the Congress - both House and Senate. The secretary of state has appeared in the several years that he's been the secretary before eighty different uh - committee hearings in the House and in the Senate. The secretary of state has made better than fifty speeches all over the United States explaining American foreign policy. I have made myself at least ten uh - speeches in various parts of the country where I have discussed with the American people defense and foreign policy.

column4: I'm not gonna name my cabinet before I get elected. I've got a little ways to go before I start doing that. But I have uh - an adequate background
column5: I believe. I am a graduate of the U.S. Naval Academy
column6: the first military graduate since uh - Eisenhower. I've served as the Governor of Georgia and have traveled extensively in foreign countries and South America
column7: Central America
column8: Europe
column9: the Middle East and in Japan. I've traveled the last twenty-one months among the people of this country. I've talked to them and I've listened. And I've seen at first hand
column10: in a very vivid way
column11: the deep hurt that's come to this country in the aftermath of Vietnam and Cambodia
column12: Chile
column13: and Pakistan
column14: and Angola
column15: and Watergate
column16: CIA revelations. What we were formerly so proud of - the strength of our country
column17: its uh - moral integrity
column18: the representation in foreign affairs of what our people are
column19: what our Constitution stands for
column20: has been gone. And in the secrecy that has surrounded our foreign policy in the last few years
column22: the Congress have been excluded. I believe I know what this country ought to be. I've uh - been one who's loved my nation as many Americans do
column23: and I believe that there's no limit placed on what we can be in the future
column24: if we can harness the tremendous resources - militarily
column25: economically
column26: and the stature of our people
column27: the meaning of the Constitution
column28: in the future. Every time we've made a serious mistake in foreign affairs
column29: it's been because the American people have been excluded from the process. If we can just tap the intelligence and ability
column30: the sound common sense and the good judgment of the American people
column31: we can once again have a foreign policy to make us proud instead of ashamed. And I'm not gonna exclude the American people from that process in the future
column32: as Mr. Ford and Kissinger have done. This is what it takes to have a sound foreign policy strong at home
column33: strong defense
column34: permanent commitments
column35: not betray the principles of our country
column36: and involve the American people and the Congress in the shaping of our foreign policy. Every time Mr. Ford speaks from a position of secrecy in negotiations
column37: in secret - in secret treaties that've been uh - pursued and achieved
column38: in supporting dictatorships
column39: in ignoring human rights
column40: we are weak and the rest of the world knows it. So these are the ways that we can restore the strength of our country
column41: and they don't require long experience in foreign policy. Nobody has that except a president who has served a long time or a secretary of state. But my background
column42: my experience
column43: my knowledge of the people of this country
column44: my commitment to our principles that don't change - those are the best bases to correct the horrible mistakes of this administration and restore our own country to a position of leadership in the world.

column1: First of all
column2: I would quit conducting the decision-making process in secret
column3: as has been a characteristic of Mr. Kissinger and Mr. Ford. In many instances we've made agreements
column4: like in Vietnam
column5: uh - that have uh - been revealed later on to our uh - embarrassment. Recently Ian Smith
column6: the uh - president of uh - Rhodesia
column7: announced that he had unequivocal commitments from Mr. Kissinger that he could not reveal. The American people don't know what those commitments are. We've seen uh - in the past the destruction of elected governments
column8: like in Chile
column9: and the strong support of military dictatorship there. These kinds of things have hurt us very much. I would restore the concept of the fireside chat
column10: which was an integral part of the administration of Franklin Roosevelt. And I would also restore the involvement of the Congress. When Harry Truman was president he was not afraid to have a strong secretary of defense. Dean Acheson
column11: George Marshall were strong secretaries of uh - state - excuse me - state. But he also made sure that there was a bipartisan support. The members of Congress
column12: Arthur Vandenberg
column13: Walter George
column14: were part of the process
column15: and before our nation made a secret agreement
column16: or before we made a bluffing statement
column17: we were sure that we had the backing not only of the president and the secretary of state
column18: but also of the Congress and the people. This is a responsibility of the president. And I think it's very damaging to our country for Mr. Ford to have turned over this responsibility to the secretary of state.

column1: Governor Carter again contradicts himself. He complains about secrecy and yet he is quoted as saying that in the attempt to find a solution in the Middle East that he would hold unpublicized meetings with the Soviet Union - I presume for the purpose of an - imposing a settlement on Israel and the Arab nations. But let me talk just a minute about what we've done to avoid secrecy in the Ford administration. After the United States took the initiative in working with Israel and with Egypt and achieving the Sinai II agreement - and I'm proud to say that not a single Egyptian or Israeli soldier has lost his life since the signing of the Sinai agreement. But at the time that uh - I submitted the Sinai agreement to the Congress of the United States
column2: I submitted every single document that was applicable to the Sinai II agreement. It was the most complete documentation by any president of any agreement signed by a president on behalf of the United States. Now as far as meeting with the Congress is concerned
column3: during the twenty-four months that I've been the president of the United States I have averaged better than one meeting a month with responsible groups or committees of the Congress - both House and Senate. The secretary of state has appeared in the several years that he's been the secretary before eighty different uh - committee hearings in the House and in the Senate. The secretary of state has made better than fifty speeches all over the United States explaining American foreign policy. I have made myself at least ten uh - speeches in various parts of the country where I have discussed with the American people defense and foreign policy.

column5: I believe.'

column8: the first military graduate since uh - Eisenhower.'
column9: ""I've served as the Governor of Georgia and have traveled extensively in foreign countries and South America
column10: Central America
column11: Europe
column12: the Middle East and in Japan.""
column13: ""I've traveled the last twenty-one months among the people of this country.""
column14: ""I've talked to them and I've listened.""
column15: ""And I've seen at first hand
column16: in a very vivid way

column18: Chile

column23: 'What we were formerly so proud of - the strength of our country
column24: its uh - moral integrity
column25: the representation in foreign affairs of what our people are

column28: 'And in the secrecy that has surrounded our foreign policy in the last few years
column29: uh - the American people

column31: 'I believe I know what this country ought to be.'
column32: ""I've uh - been one who's loved my nation as many Americans do
column33: and I believe that there's no limit placed on what we can be in the future
column34: if we can harness the tremendous resources - militarily
column36: and the stature of our people
column37: the meaning of the Constitution
column38: in the future.""
column39: ""Every time we've made a serious mistake in foreign affairs

column41: 'If we can just tap the intelligence and ability
column42: the sound common sense and the good judgment of the American people
column43: we can once again have a foreign policy to make us proud instead of ashamed.'
column44: ""And I'm not gonna exclude the American people from that process in the future
column45: as Mr. Ford and Kissinger have done.""
column46: 'This is what it takes to have a sound foreign policy strong at home
column47: strong defense
column48: permanent commitments
column49: not betray the principles of our country
column50: and involve the American people and the Congress in the shaping of our foreign policy.'
column51: ""Every time Mr. Ford speaks from a position of secrecy in negotiations
column52: in secret - in secret treaties that've been uh - pursued and achieved
column54: in ignoring human rights
column55: we are weak and the rest of the world knows it.""
column56: ""So these are the ways that we can restore the strength of our country
column57: and they don't require long experience in foreign policy.""
column58: 'Nobody has that except a president who has served a long time or a secretary of state.'
column59: ""But my background
column60: my experience
column61: my knowledge of the people of this country
column62: my commitment to our principles that don't change - those are the best bases to correct the horrible mistakes of this administration and restore our own country to a position of leadership in the world.""
column64: I would quit conducting the decision-making process in secret

column67: like in Vietnam

column3: 5)	" I would never single out food as a trade embargo item. If I ever decided to impose an embargo because of a crisis in international relationships
column4: it would include all shipments of all equipment. For instance
column5: if the Arab countries ever again declare an embargo against our nation on oil I would consider that not a military but an economic declaration of war
column6: and I would respond instantly and in kind. I would not ship that Arab country anything - no weapons
column7: no spare parts for weapons
column8: no oil-drilling rigs
column9: no oil pipe
column10: no nothing. I wouldn't single out just food. Another thing that I'd like to say is this: In our international trade
column11: as I said in my op- opening statement
column12: we have become the arms merchant of the world. When this Republican administration came into office we were shipping about $1 billion worth of arms overseas
column13: now ten to twelve billion dollars worth of arms overseas to countries that quite often use these weapons to fight each other. The shift in emphasis has been very disturbing to me
column14: speaking about the Middle East. Under the last Democratic administration 60 percent of all weapons that went into the Middle East were for Israel. Nowadays - 75 percent were for Israel before. Now 60 percent go to the Arab countries
column15: and this does not include Iran. If you include Iran
column16: our present shipment of weapons to the Middle East
column17: only 20 percent goes to Israel. This is a deviation from idealism; it's a deviation from a commitment to our major ally in the Middle East
column18: which is Israel; it's a yielding to economic pressure on the part of the Arabs on the oil issue; and it's also a tremendous indication that under the Ford administration we have not addressed the energy policy adequately. We still have no comprehensive energy policy in this country. And it's an overall sign of weakness. When we are weak at home economically - high unemployment
column19: high inflation
column20: a confused government
column22: this encourages the kind of pressure that's been put on us successfully. It would've been inconceivable ten - fifteen years ago
column23: for us to be brought to our knees with an Arab oil embargo. But it was done three years ago and they're still putting pressure on us from the Arab countries to our discredit around the world. These are the weaknesses that I see
column24: and I believe it's not just a matter of idealism. It's a matter of being tough. It's a matter of being strong. It's a matter of being consistent. Our priorities ought to be first of all to meet our own military needs
column25: secondly to meet the needs of our allies and friends
column26: and only then should we ship military equipment to foreign countries. As a matter of fact
column27: Iran is gonna get eighty F-14s before we even meet our own Air Force orders for F-l4s. And the shipment of Spruance-class destroyers to Iran are much more highly sophisticated than the Spruance-class destroyers that are present being delivered to our own Navy. This is ridiculous and it ought to be changed.

column1: If - Iran is not an Arab country
column3: it is a Moslem country - but if Saudi Arabia should declare an oil embargo against us
column4: then I would consider that an economic declaration of war. And I would make sure that the uh - Saudis understood this ahead of time so there would be no doubt in their mind. I think under those circumstances they would refrain from pushing us to our knees as they did in 1973 with their previous oil embargo.

column1: Governor Carter uh - apparently doesn't realize that since I've been president we have sold to the Israelis over $4 billion in military hardware. We have made available to the Israelis over 45 percent of the total economic and military aid since the establishment of Israel twenty-seven years ago. So the Ford administration has done a good job in helping our good ally
column3: and we're dedicated to the survival and security of Israel. I believe that Governor Carter doesn't realize the need and necessity for arms sales to Iran. He indicates he would not make those. Iran is bordered very extensively by the Soviet Union. Iran has Iraq as one of its neighbors. The Soviet Union and the Communist-dominated government of Iraq are neighbors of Iran
column4: and Iran is an ally of the United States. It's my strong feeling that we ought to sell arms to Iran for its own national security
column5: and as an ally - a strong ally of the United States. The history of our relationship with Iran goes back to the days of President Truman when he decided that it was vitally necessary for our own security as well as that of Iran
column6: that we should help that country
column7: and Iran has been a good ally. In 1973 when there was an oil embargo
column8: Iran did not participate. Iran continued to sell oil to the United States. I believe that it's in our interest and in the interest of Israel and Iran
column9: and Saudi Arabia
column10: for the United States to sell arms to those countries. It's for their security as well as ours.
