column2: 'If I ever decided to impose an embargo because of a crisis in international relationships
column3: it would include all shipments of all equipment.'
column4: 'For instance
column5: if the Arab countries ever again declare an embargo against our nation on oil I would consider that not a military but an economic declaration of war
column6: and I would respond instantly and in kind.'
column7: 'I would not ship that Arab country anything - no weapons
column8: no spare parts for weapons
column9: no oil-drilling rigs
column10: no oil pipe
column11: no nothing.'
column12: ""I wouldn't single out just food.""
column13: ""Another thing that I'd like to say is this: In our international trade
column14: as I said in my op- opening statement
column15: we have become the arms merchant of the world.""
column16: 'When this Republican administration came into office we were shipping about $1 billion worth of arms overseas
column17: now ten to twelve billion dollars worth of arms overseas to countries that quite often use these weapons to fight each other.'
column18: 'The shift in emphasis has been very disturbing to me
column19: speaking about the Middle East.'
column20: 'Under the last Democratic administration 60 percent of all weapons that went into the Middle East were for Israel.'
column22: 'Now 60 percent go to the Arab countries
column23: and this does not include Iran.'
column24: 'If you include Iran
column25: our present shipment of weapons to the Middle East
column26: only 20 percent goes to Israel.'
column27: ""This is a deviation from idealism; it's a deviation from a commitment to our major ally in the Middle East
column28: which is Israel; it's a yielding to economic pressure on the part of the Arabs on the oil issue; and it's also a tremendous indication that under the Ford administration we have not addressed the energy policy adequately.""
column29: 'We still have no comprehensive energy policy in this country.'
column30: ""And it's an overall sign of weakness.""
column31: ""When we are weak at home economically - high unemployment
column33: a confused government
column34: a wasteful defense establishment
column35: this encourages the kind of pressure that's been put on us successfully.""
column36: ""It would've been inconceivable ten - fifteen years ago
column37: for us to be brought to our knees with an Arab oil embargo.""
column38: ""But it was done three years ago and they're still putting pressure on us from the Arab countries to our discredit around the world.""
column39: ""These are the weaknesses that I see
column40: and I believe it's not just a matter of idealism.""
column41: ""It's a matter of being tough.""
column42: ""It's a matter of being strong.""
column43: ""It's a matter of being consistent.""
column44: 'Our priorities ought to be first of all to meet our own military needs
column45: secondly to meet the needs of our allies and friends
column46: and only then should we ship military equipment to foreign countries.'
column47: 'As a matter of fact
column48: Iran is gonna get eighty F-14s before we even meet our own Air Force orders for F-l4s.'
column49: 'And the shipment of Spruance-class destroyers to Iran are much more highly sophisticated than the Spruance-class destroyers that are present being delivered to our own Navy.'
column50: 'This is ridiculous and it ought to be changed.'
column51: 'If - Iran is not an Arab country
column53: it is a Moslem country - but if Saudi Arabia should declare an oil embargo against us
column54: then I would consider that an economic declaration of war.'
column55: 'And I would make sure that the uh - Saudis understood this ahead of time so there would be no doubt in their mind.'
column56: 'I think under those circumstances they would refrain from pushing us to our knees as they did in 1973 with their previous oil embargo.'
column57: ""Governor Carter uh - apparently doesn't realize that since I've been president we have sold to the Israelis over $4 billion in military hardware.""
column58: 'We have made available to the Israelis over 45 percent of the total economic and military aid since the establishment of Israel twenty-seven years ago.'
column59: ""So the Ford administration has done a good job in helping our good ally
column60: Israel
column61: and we're dedicated to the survival and security of Israel.""
column62: ""I believe that Governor Carter doesn't realize the need and necessity for arms sales to Iran.""

column64: 'Iran is bordered very extensively by the Soviet Union.'
column65: 'Iran has Iraq as one of its neighbors.'
column66: 'The Soviet Union and the Communist-dominated government of Iraq are neighbors of Iran
column67: and Iran is an ally of the United States.'
column68: ""It's my strong feeling that we ought to sell arms to Iran for its own national security
column69: and as an ally - a strong ally of the United States.""
column70: 'The history of our relationship with Iran goes back to the days of President Truman when he decided that it was vitally necessary for our own security as well as that of Iran
column71: that we should help that country
column72: and Iran has been a good ally.'

column3: 7)	" Well
column4: always in the past we've had an ability to have a strong defense and also have - to have a strong uh - domestic economy
column5: and also to be strong in our reputation and influence within the community of nations. These uh - characteristics of our country have been endangered under Mr. Ford. We're no longer respected in a showdown vote in the United Nations or in - in any other international council we're lucky to get 20 percent of the other nations to vote with us. Our allies feel that we've neglected them. The so-called Nixon shock against Japan had weakened our relationships there. Under this administration we've also had an inclination to keep separate the European countries
column6: thinking that if they are separate
column7: then we can dominate them and proceed with our secret
column8: Lone Ranger-type diplomatic efforts. I would uh - also like to point out that we
column9: in this country
column10: have let our economy go down the drain. The worst inflation since the Great Depression. The highest unemployment of any developed nation of the world. We have a higher unemployment rate in this country than Great Britain
column11: and West Germany. Our unemployment rate is twice as high as it is in Italy; it's three or four times as high as it is - as it is in Japan. And that terrible circumstance in this country is exported overseas. We comprise about 30 percent of the world's economic trade power influence. And when we're weak at home - weaker than all our allies - that weakness weakens the whole free world. So strong economy is very important. Another thing that we need to do is to reestablish the good relationships that we ought to have between the United States and our natural allies and friends. They have felt neglected. And using that base of strength
column12: and using the idealism
column13: the honesty
column14: the predictability
column15: the commitment
column16: the integrity of our own country
column17: that's where our strength lies. And that would permit us to deal with the developing nations in a position of strength. Under this administration we've had a continuation of the so-called balance of power politics
column18: where everything is looked on as a struggle between us on the one side
column19: the Soviet Union on the other. Our allies - the smaller countries get trampled in the rush. What we need is to try to seek individualized bilateral relationships with countries
column20: regardless of their size
column22: which means that we want to preserve peace through strength. We also wanna revert back to the stature and the respect that our country had in previous administrations. Now
column23: I can't say when this can come. But I can guarantee it will not come if Gerald Ford is reelected and this present policy is continued; it will come if I'm elected.

column1: Well let me say very quickly that under President Johnson
column2: in spite of the massive investment in the Vietnam War
column3: he turned over a balanced budget to Mr. Nixon. The unemployment rate was less than 4 percent. The inflation rate under Kennedy and Johnson was about 2 percent - one-third what it is under this administration. So we did have at that time with good management
column4: the ability to do both. I don't think that anybody can say that Johnson and Kennedy neglected the poor and the destitute people in this country or around the world. But I can say this: The number one responsibility of any president
column5: above all else
column6: is to guarantee the security of our nation - an ability to be free of the threat of attack
column7: or blackmail and to carry out our obligations to our allies and friends
column8: and to carry out a legitimate foreign policy. They must go hand in hand
column9: but the security of this nation has got to come first.

column1: Let me say very categorically you cannot maintain the security of the United States with the kind of defense budget cuts that Governor Carter has indicated. In 1975 he wanted to cut the budget $15 billion. He's now down to a figure of five to seven billion dollars. Reductions of that kind will not permit the United States to be strong enough to deter aggression and maintain the peace. Governor Carter apparently doesn't know the facts. As soon as I became president
column2: I initiated a meeting with the NATO heads of state and met with them in Brussels to discuss how we could improve the re- defense relationship in Western Europe. In uh - November of 1975 I met with the leaders of the five industrial nations in France for the purpose of seeing what we could do acting together to meet the problems of uh - the coming recession. In Puerto Rico this year
column3: I met with six of the leading industrial nations' heads of state to meet the problem of inflation so we would be able to solve it before it got out of hand. I have met with the heads of government bilaterally as well as multilaterally. Our relations with Japan have never been better. I was the first United States president to visit Japan. And we uh - had the emperor of Japan here this uh - past year and the net result is Japan and the United States are working more closely together now than at any time in the history of our relationship. You can go around the world - and let me take Israel for example. Just recently
column4: President Rabin said that our relations were never better.

Reductions of that kind will not permit the United States to be strong enough to deter aggression and maintain the peace. Governor Carter apparently doesn't know the facts. column2: I initiated a meeting with the NATO heads of state and met with them in Brussels to discuss how we could improve the re- defense relationship in Western Europe. In uh - November of 1975 I met with the leaders of the five industrial nations in France for the purpose of seeing what we could do acting together to meet the problems of uh - the coming recession. In Puerto Rico this year
column3: I met with six of the leading industrial nations' heads of state to meet the problem of inflation so we would be able to solve it before it got out of hand. I have met with the heads of government bilaterally as well as multilaterally. Our relations with Japan have never been better. I was the first United States president to visit Japan. And we uh - had the emperor of Japan here this uh - past year and the net result is Japan and the United States are working more closely together now than at any time in the history of our relationship. You can go around the world - and let me take Israel for example. Just recently
column4: President Rabin said that our relations were never better.

column3: 7)	" Well
column4: always in the past we've had an ability to have a strong defense and also have - to have a strong uh - domestic economy
column5: and also to be strong in our reputation and influence within the community of nations. These uh - characteristics of our country have been endangered under Mr. Ford. We're no longer respected in a showdown vote in the United Nations or in - in any other international council we're lucky to get 20 percent of the other nations to vote with us. Our allies feel that we've neglected them. The so-called Nixon shock against Japan had weakened our relationships there. Under this administration we've also had an inclination to keep separate the European countries
column6: thinking that if they are separate
column7: then we can dominate them and proceed with our secret
column8: Lone Ranger-type diplomatic efforts. I would uh - also like to point out that we
column9: in this country
column10: have let our economy go down the drain. The worst inflation since the Great Depression. The highest unemployment of any developed nation of the world. We have a higher unemployment rate in this country than Great Britain
column11: and West Germany. Our unemployment rate is twice as high as it is in Italy; it's three or four times as high as it is - as it is in Japan. And that terrible circumstance in this country is exported overseas. We comprise about 30 percent of the world's economic trade power influence. And when we're weak at home - weaker than all our allies - that weakness weakens the whole free world. So strong economy is very important. Another thing that we need to do is to reestablish the good relationships that we ought to have between the United States and our natural allies and friends. They have felt neglected. And using that base of strength
column12: and using the idealism
column13: the honesty
column14: the predictability
column15: the commitment
column16: the integrity of our own country
column17: that's where our strength lies. And that would permit us to deal with the developing nations in a position of strength. Under this administration we've had a continuation of the so-called balance of power politics
column18: where everything is looked on as a struggle between us on the one side
column19: the Soviet Union on the other. Our allies - the smaller countries get trampled in the rush. What we need is to try to seek individualized bilateral relationships with countries
column20: regardless of their size
column22: which means that we want to preserve peace through strength. We also wanna revert back to the stature and the respect that our country had in previous administrations. Now
column23: I can't say when this can come. But I can guarantee it will not come if Gerald Ford is reelected and this present policy is continued; it will come if I'm elected.

column1: Well let me say very quickly that under President Johnson
column2: in spite of the massive investment in the Vietnam War
column3: he turned over a balanced budget to Mr. Nixon. The unemployment rate was less than 4 percent. The inflation rate under Kennedy and Johnson was about 2 percent - one-third what it is under this administration. So we did have at that time with good management
column4: the ability to do both. I don't think that anybody can say that Johnson and Kennedy neglected the poor and the destitute people in this country or around the world. But I can say this: The number one responsibility of any president
column5: above all else
column6: is to guarantee the security of our nation - an ability to be free of the threat of attack
column7: or blackmail and to carry out our obligations to our allies and friends
column8: and to carry out a legitimate foreign policy. They must go hand in hand
column9: but the security of this nation has got to come first.

column1: Let me say very categorically you cannot maintain the security of the United States with the kind of defense budget cuts that Governor Carter has indicated. In 1975 he wanted to cut the budget $15 billion. He's now down to a figure of five to seven billion dollars. Reductions of that kind will not permit the United States to be strong enough to deter aggression and maintain the peace. Governor Carter apparently doesn't know the facts. As soon as I became president
column2: I initiated a meeting with the NATO heads of state and met with them in Brussels to discuss how we could improve the re- defense relationship in Western Europe. In uh - November of 1975 I met with the leaders of the five industrial nations in France for the purpose of seeing what we could do acting together to meet the problems of uh - the coming recession. In Puerto Rico this year
column3: I met with six of the leading industrial nations' heads of state to meet the problem of inflation so we would be able to solve it before it got out of hand. I have met with the heads of government bilaterally as well as multilaterally. Our relations with Japan have never been better. I was the first United States president to visit Japan. And we uh - had the emperor of Japan here this uh - past year and the net result is Japan and the United States are working more closely together now than at any time in the history of our relationship. You can go around the world - and let me take Israel for example. Just recently
column4: President Rabin said that our relations were never better.

column4: always in the past we've had an ability to have a strong defense and also have - to have a strong uh - domestic economy
column5: and also to be strong in our reputation and influence within the community of nations. These uh - characteristics of our country have been endangered under Mr. Ford. We're no longer respected in a showdown vote in the United Nations or in - in any other international council we're lucky to get 20 percent of the other nations to vote with us. Our allies feel that we've neglected them. The so-called Nixon shock against Japan had weakened our relationships there. Under this administration we've also had an inclination to keep separate the European countries
column6: thinking that if they are separate
column7: then we can dominate them and proceed with our secret
column8: Lone Ranger-type diplomatic efforts. I would uh - also like to point out that we
column9: in this country
column10: have let our economy go down the drain. The worst inflation since the Great Depression. The highest unemployment of any developed nation of the world. We have a higher unemployment rate in this country than Great Britain
column11: and West Germany. Our unemployment rate is twice as high as it is in Italy; it's three or four times as high as it is - as it is in Japan. And that terrible circumstance in this country is exported overseas. We comprise about 30 percent of the world's economic trade power influence. And when we're weak at home - weaker than all our allies - that weakness weakens the whole free world. So strong economy is very important. Another thing that we need to do is to reestablish the good relationships that we ought to have between the United States and our natural allies and friends. They have felt neglected. And using that base of strength
column12: and using the idealism
column13: the honesty
column14: the predictability
column15: the commitment
column16: the integrity of our own country
column17: that's where our strength lies. And that would permit us to deal with the developing nations in a position of strength. Under this administration we've had a continuation of the so-called balance of power politics
column18: where everything is looked on as a struggle between us on the one side
column19: the Soviet Union on the other. Our allies - the smaller countries get trampled in the rush. What we need is to try to seek individualized bilateral relationships with countries
column20: regardless of their size
column22: which means that we want to preserve peace through strength. We also wanna revert back to the stature and the respect that our country had in previous administrations. Now
column23: I can't say when this can come. But I can guarantee it will not come if Gerald Ford is reelected and this present policy is continued; it will come if I'm elected.

column1: Well let me say very quickly that under President Johnson
column2: in spite of the massive investment in the Vietnam War
column3: he turned over a balanced budget to Mr. Nixon. The unemployment rate was less than 4 percent. The inflation rate under Kennedy and Johnson was about 2 percent - one-third what it is under this administration. So we did have at that time with good management
column4: the ability to do both. I don't think that anybody can say that Johnson and Kennedy neglected the poor and the destitute people in this country or around the world. But I can say this: The number one responsibility of any president
column5: above all else
column6: is to guarantee the security of our nation - an ability to be free of the threat of attack
column7: or blackmail and to carry out our obligations to our allies and friends
column8: and to carry out a legitimate foreign policy. They must go hand in hand
column9: but the security of this nation has got to come first.

column1: Let me say very categorically you cannot maintain the security of the United States with the kind of defense budget cuts that Governor Carter has indicated. In 1975 he wanted to cut the budget $15 billion. He's now down to a figure of five to seven billion dollars. Reductions of that kind will not permit the United States to be strong enough to deter aggression and maintain the peace. Governor Carter apparently doesn't know the facts. As soon as I became president
column2: I initiated a meeting with the NATO heads of state and met with them in Brussels to discuss how we could improve the re- defense relationship in Western Europe. In uh - November of 1975 I met with the leaders of the five industrial nations in France for the purpose of seeing what we could do acting together to meet the problems of uh - the coming recession. In Puerto Rico this year
column3: I met with six of the leading industrial nations' heads of state to meet the problem of inflation so we would be able to solve it before it got out of hand. I have met with the heads of government bilaterally as well as multilaterally. Our relations with Japan have never been better. I was the first United States president to visit Japan. And we uh - had the emperor of Japan here this uh - past year and the net result is Japan and the United States are working more closely together now than at any time in the history of our relationship. You can go around the world - and let me take Israel for example. Just recently
column4: President Rabin said that our relations were never better.

column3: 8)	" First we have to understand that SALT I expires October third 1977. Uh - Mr. Brezhnev and I met in Vladivostok in December of 1974 for the purpose of trying to take the initial step so we could have a SALT II agreement that would go to l985. As I indicated earlier
column4: we did agree on a twenty-four-hundred limitation on uh - uh - launchers of ballistic missiles. Uh - that would mean a cutback in the Soviet program; it would not interfere with our own program. At the same time
column5: we put a limitation of thirteen hundred and twenty on MIRVs. Our technicians have been working since that time in Geneva
column6: trying to put into technical language a - an agreement that can be verified by both parties. In the meantime
column7: there has developed the problem of the Soviet Backfire - their high-performance aircraft which they say is not a long-range aircraft and which some of our people say is a intercontinental aircraft. In the interim
column8: there has been the development on our part primarily
column9: the cruise missiles; cruise missiles that could be launched from land-based mobile installations; cruise missiles that could be launched - launched from high-performance aircraft
column10: like the B-52s or the B-1s
column11: which I hope we proceed with; cruise missiles which could be launched from either surface or submarine uh - naval vessels. Those gray-area weapons systems are creating some problems in a - the agreement for a SALT II negotiation. But I can say that I am dedicated to proceeding
column12: and I met just last week with the foreign minister of the Soviet Union
column13: and he indicated to me that uh - the Soviet Union was interested in narrowing the differences and making a realistic and a sound compromise. I hope and trust
column14: in the best interest of both countries
column15: and in the best interests of all people throughout this globe
column16: that the Soviet Union and the United States can make a mutually beneficial agreement. Because if we do not and SALT I expires on October three
column18: you will unleash again an all-out nuclear arms race with the potential of a nuclear holocaust of unbelievable dimensions. So it's the obligation of the president to do just that
column19: and I intend to do so.

column1: I believe that the cruise missiles which we are now developing in research and development across the spectrum from air
column3: or from the land
column4: uh - can be uh - included within a SALT II agreement. They are a new weapons system that has a great potential
column5: both conventional and nuclear armed. At the same time
column6: we have to make certain that the Soviet Union's Backfire
column7: which they claim is not an intercontinental aircraft and which some of our people contend is
column8: must also be included if we are to get the kind of agreement which is in the best interest of both countries. And I really believe that it - it's far better for us and for the Soviet Union
column9: and more importantly for the people around the world
column10: that these two superpowers find an answer for a SALT II agreement before October three
column11: 1977. I think good will on both parts
column12: hard bargaining by both parties and a reasonable compromise will be in the best interests of all parties.

column1: Well
column2: Mr. Ford acts like he's uh - running for president for the first time. He's been in office two years
column3: and there has been absolutely no progress made toward a new SALT agreement. He has learned the date of the expiration of SALT I
column4: apparently. We've seen
column5: in this world
column6: a development of a tremendous threat to us. As a nuclear engineer myself
column7: I know the limitations and capabilities of atomic power. I also - know that as far as the human beings on this earth are concerned that the nonproliferation of atomic weapons is number one. Only the last few days with the election approaching
column8: has Mr. Ford taken any interest in a nonproliferation movement. I advocated last May in a speech at the United Nations that we move immediately as a nation to declare a complete moratorium on the testing of all nuclear devices
column9: both weapons and peaceful devices; that we not ship any more atomic fuel to a country that refuses to comply with strict controls over the waste which can be reprocessed into explosives. I've also advocated that we stop the sale by Germany and France of - processing plants for Pakistan and Brazil. Mr. Ford hasn't moved on this. We also need to provide an adequate supply of enriched uranium. Mr. Ford
column10: again
column11: under pressure from the atomic energy lobby
column12: has insisted that this reprocessing or rather re-en- enrichment be done by private industry and not by the existing uh - government uh - plants. This kind of confusion and absence of leadership has let us drift now for two years with a constantly increasing threat of atomic weapons throughout the world. We now have five nations that have atomic bombs that we know about. If we continue under Mr. Ford's policy by 1985 or '90 we'll have twenty nations that have the capability of exploding atomic weapons. This has got to be stopped. That is one of the major challenges and major undertakings that I will assume as the next president.

column3: 8)	" First we have to understand that SALT I expires October third 1977. Uh - Mr. Brezhnev and I met in Vladivostok in December of 1974 for the purpose of trying to take the initial step so we could have a SALT II agreement that would go to l985. As I indicated earlier
column4: we did agree on a twenty-four-hundred limitation on uh - uh - launchers of ballistic missiles. Uh - that would mean a cutback in the Soviet program; it would not interfere with our own program. At the same time
column5: we put a limitation of thirteen hundred and twenty on MIRVs. Our technicians have been working since that time in Geneva
column6: trying to put into technical language a - an agreement that can be verified by both parties. In the meantime
column7: there has developed the problem of the Soviet Backfire - their high-performance aircraft which they say is not a long-range aircraft and which some of our people say is a intercontinental aircraft. In the interim
column8: there has been the development on our part primarily
column9: the cruise missiles; cruise missiles that could be launched from land-based mobile installations; cruise missiles that could be launched - launched from high-performance aircraft
column10: like the B-52s or the B-1s
column11: which I hope we proceed with; cruise missiles which could be launched from either surface or submarine uh - naval vessels. Those gray-area weapons systems are creating some problems in a - the agreement for a SALT II negotiation. But I can say that I am dedicated to proceeding
column12: and I met just last week with the foreign minister of the Soviet Union
column13: and he indicated to me that uh - the Soviet Union was interested in narrowing the differences and making a realistic and a sound compromise. I hope and trust
column14: in the best interest of both countries
column15: and in the best interests of all people throughout this globe
column16: that the Soviet Union and the United States can make a mutually beneficial agreement. Because if we do not and SALT I expires on October three
column18: you will unleash again an all-out nuclear arms race with the potential of a nuclear holocaust of unbelievable dimensions. So it's the obligation of the president to do just that
column19: and I intend to do so.

column1: I believe that the cruise missiles which we are now developing in research and development across the spectrum from air
column3: or from the land
column4: uh - can be uh - included within a SALT II agreement. They are a new weapons system that has a great potential
column5: both conventional and nuclear armed. At the same time
column6: we have to make certain that the Soviet Union's Backfire
column7: which they claim is not an intercontinental aircraft and which some of our people contend is
column8: must also be included if we are to get the kind of agreement which is in the best interest of both countries. And I really believe that it - it's far better for us and for the Soviet Union
column9: and more importantly for the people around the world
column10: that these two superpowers find an answer for a SALT II agreement before October three
column11: 1977. I think good will on both parts
column12: hard bargaining by both parties and a reasonable compromise will be in the best interests of all parties.

column1: Well
column2: Mr. Ford acts like he's uh - running for president for the first time. He's been in office two years
column3: and there has been absolutely no progress made toward a new SALT agreement. He has learned the date of the expiration of SALT I
column4: apparently. We've seen
column5: in this world
column6: a development of a tremendous threat to us. As a nuclear engineer myself
column7: I know the limitations and capabilities of atomic power. I also - know that as far as the human beings on this earth are concerned that the nonproliferation of atomic weapons is number one. Only the last few days with the election approaching
column8: has Mr. Ford taken any interest in a nonproliferation movement. I advocated last May in a speech at the United Nations that we move immediately as a nation to declare a complete moratorium on the testing of all nuclear devices
column9: both weapons and peaceful devices; that we not ship any more atomic fuel to a country that refuses to comply with strict controls over the waste which can be reprocessed into explosives. I've also advocated that we stop the sale by Germany and France of - processing plants for Pakistan and Brazil. Mr. Ford hasn't moved on this. We also need to provide an adequate supply of enriched uranium. Mr. Ford
column10: again
column11: under pressure from the atomic energy lobby
column12: has insisted that this reprocessing or rather re-en- enrichment be done by private industry and not by the existing uh - government uh - plants. This kind of confusion and absence of leadership has let us drift now for two years with a constantly increasing threat of atomic weapons throughout the world. We now have five nations that have atomic bombs that we know about. If we continue under Mr. Ford's policy by 1985 or '90 we'll have twenty nations that have the capability of exploding atomic weapons. This has got to be stopped. That is one of the major challenges and major undertakings that I will assume as the next president.

column3: 8)	" First we have to understand that SALT I expires October third 1977. Uh - Mr. Brezhnev and I met in Vladivostok in December of 1974 for the purpose of trying to take the initial step so we could have a SALT II agreement that would go to l985. As I indicated earlier
column4: we did agree on a twenty-four-hundred limitation on uh - uh - launchers of ballistic missiles. Uh - that would mean a cutback in the Soviet program; it would not interfere with our own program. At the same time
column5: we put a limitation of thirteen hundred and twenty on MIRVs. Our technicians have been working since that time in Geneva
column6: trying to put into technical language a - an agreement that can be verified by both parties. In the meantime
column7: there has developed the problem of the Soviet Backfire - their high-performance aircraft which they say is not a long-range aircraft and which some of our people say is a intercontinental aircraft. In the interim
column8: there has been the development on our part primarily
column9: the cruise missiles; cruise missiles that could be launched from land-based mobile installations; cruise missiles that could be launched - launched from high-performance aircraft
column10: like the B-52s or the B-1s
column11: which I hope we proceed with; cruise missiles which could be launched from either surface or submarine uh - naval vessels. Those gray-area weapons systems are creating some problems in a - the agreement for a SALT II negotiation. But I can say that I am dedicated to proceeding
column12: and I met just last week with the foreign minister of the Soviet Union
column13: and he indicated to me that uh - the Soviet Union was interested in narrowing the differences and making a realistic and a sound compromise. I hope and trust
column14: in the best interest of both countries
column15: and in the best interests of all people throughout this globe
column16: that the Soviet Union and the United States can make a mutually beneficial agreement. Because if we do not and SALT I expires on October three
column18: you will unleash again an all-out nuclear arms race with the potential of a nuclear holocaust of unbelievable dimensions. So it's the obligation of the president to do just that
column19: and I intend to do so.

column1: I believe that the cruise missiles which we are now developing in research and development across the spectrum from air
column3: or from the land
column4: uh - can be uh - included within a SALT II agreement. They are a new weapons system that has a great potential
column5: both conventional and nuclear armed. At the same time
column6: we have to make certain that the Soviet Union's Backfire
column7: which they claim is not an intercontinental aircraft and which some of our people contend is
column8: must also be included if we are to get the kind of agreement which is in the best interest of both countries. And I really believe that it - it's far better for us and for the Soviet Union
column9: and more importantly for the people around the world
column10: that these two superpowers find an answer for a SALT II agreement before October three
column11: 1977. I think good will on both parts
column12: hard bargaining by both parties and a reasonable compromise will be in the best interests of all parties.

column1: Well
column2: Mr. Ford acts like he's uh - running for president for the first time. He's been in office two years
column3: and there has been absolutely no progress made toward a new SALT agreement. He has learned the date of the expiration of SALT I
column4: apparently. We've seen
column5: in this world
column6: a development of a tremendous threat to us. As a nuclear engineer myself
column7: I know the limitations and capabilities of atomic power. I also - know that as far as the human beings on this earth are concerned that the nonproliferation of atomic weapons is number one. Only the last few days with the election approaching
column8: has Mr. Ford taken any interest in a nonproliferation movement. I advocated last May in a speech at the United Nations that we move immediately as a nation to declare a complete moratorium on the testing of all nuclear devices
column9: both weapons and peaceful devices; that we not ship any more atomic fuel to a country that refuses to comply with strict controls over the waste which can be reprocessed into explosives. I've also advocated that we stop the sale by Germany and France of - processing plants for Pakistan and Brazil. Mr. Ford hasn't moved on this. We also need to provide an adequate supply of enriched uranium. Mr. Ford
column10: again
column11: under pressure from the atomic energy lobby
column12: has insisted that this reprocessing or rather re-en- enrichment be done by private industry and not by the existing uh - government uh - plants. This kind of confusion and absence of leadership has let us drift now for two years with a constantly increasing threat of atomic weapons throughout the world. We now have five nations that have atomic bombs that we know about. If we continue under Mr. Ford's policy by 1985 or '90 we'll have twenty nations that have the capability of exploding atomic weapons. This has got to be stopped. That is one of the major challenges and major undertakings that I will assume as the next president.

column3: 8)	" First we have to understand that SALT I expires October third 1977. Uh - Mr. Brezhnev and I met in Vladivostok in December of 1974 for the purpose of trying to take the initial step so we could have a SALT II agreement that would go to l985. As I indicated earlier
column4: we did agree on a twenty-four-hundred limitation on uh - uh - launchers of ballistic missiles. Uh - that would mean a cutback in the Soviet program; it would not interfere with our own program. At the same time
column5: we put a limitation of thirteen hundred and twenty on MIRVs. Our technicians have been working since that time in Geneva
column6: trying to put into technical language a - an agreement that can be verified by both parties. In the meantime
column7: there has developed the problem of the Soviet Backfire - their high-performance aircraft which they say is not a long-range aircraft and which some of our people say is a intercontinental aircraft. In the interim
column8: there has been the development on our part primarily
column9: the cruise missiles; cruise missiles that could be launched from land-based mobile installations; cruise missiles that could be launched - launched from high-performance aircraft
column10: like the B-52s or the B-1s
column11: which I hope we proceed with; cruise missiles which could be launched from either surface or submarine uh - naval vessels. Those gray-area weapons systems are creating some problems in a - the agreement for a SALT II negotiation. But I can say that I am dedicated to proceeding
column12: and I met just last week with the foreign minister of the Soviet Union
column13: and he indicated to me that uh - the Soviet Union was interested in narrowing the differences and making a realistic and a sound compromise. I hope and trust
column14: in the best interest of both countries
column15: and in the best interests of all people throughout this globe
column16: that the Soviet Union and the United States can make a mutually beneficial agreement. Because if we do not and SALT I expires on October three
column18: you will unleash again an all-out nuclear arms race with the potential of a nuclear holocaust of unbelievable dimensions. So it's the obligation of the president to do just that
column19: and I intend to do so.

column1: I believe that the cruise missiles which we are now developing in research and development across the spectrum from air
column3: or from the land
column4: uh - can be uh - included within a SALT II agreement. They are a new weapons system that has a great potential
column5: both conventional and nuclear armed. At the same time
column6: we have to make certain that the Soviet Union's Backfire
column7: which they claim is not an intercontinental aircraft and which some of our people contend is
column8: must also be included if we are to get the kind of agreement which is in the best interest of both countries. And I really believe that it - it's far better for us and for the Soviet Union
column9: and more importantly for the people around the world
column10: that these two superpowers find an answer for a SALT II agreement before October three
column11: 1977. I think good will on both parts
column12: hard bargaining by both parties and a reasonable compromise will be in the best interests of all parties.

column1: Well
column2: Mr. Ford acts like he's uh - running for president for the first time. He's been in office two years
column3: and there has been absolutely no progress made toward a new SALT agreement. He has learned the date of the expiration of SALT I
column4: apparently. We've seen
column5: in this world
column6: a development of a tremendous threat to us. As a nuclear engineer myself
column7: I know the limitations and capabilities of atomic power. I also - know that as far as the human beings on this earth are concerned that the nonproliferation of atomic weapons is number one. Only the last few days with the election approaching
column8: has Mr. Ford taken any interest in a nonproliferation movement. I advocated last May in a speech at the United Nations that we move immediately as a nation to declare a complete moratorium on the testing of all nuclear devices
column9: both weapons and peaceful devices; that we not ship any more atomic fuel to a country that refuses to comply with strict controls over the waste which can be reprocessed into explosives. I've also advocated that we stop the sale by Germany and France of - processing plants for Pakistan and Brazil. Mr. Ford hasn't moved on this. We also need to provide an adequate supply of enriched uranium. Mr. Ford
column10: again
column11: under pressure from the atomic energy lobby
column12: has insisted that this reprocessing or rather re-en- enrichment be done by private industry and not by the existing uh - government uh - plants. This kind of confusion and absence of leadership has let us drift now for two years with a constantly increasing threat of atomic weapons throughout the world. We now have five nations that have atomic bombs that we know about. If we continue under Mr. Ford's policy by 1985 or '90 we'll have twenty nations that have the capability of exploding atomic weapons. This has got to be stopped. That is one of the major challenges and major undertakings that I will assume as the next president.

column3: 8)	" First we have to understand that SALT I expires October third 1977. Uh - Mr. Brezhnev and I met in Vladivostok in December of 1974 for the purpose of trying to take the initial step so we could have a SALT II agreement that would go to l985. As I indicated earlier
column4: we did agree on a twenty-four-hundred limitation on uh - uh - launchers of ballistic missiles. Uh - that would mean a cutback in the Soviet program; it would not interfere with our own program. At the same time
column5: we put a limitation of thirteen hundred and twenty on MIRVs. Our technicians have been working since that time in Geneva
column6: trying to put into technical language a - an agreement that can be verified by both parties. In the meantime
column7: there has developed the problem of the Soviet Backfire - their high-performance aircraft which they say is not a long-range aircraft and which some of our people say is a intercontinental aircraft. In the interim
column8: there has been the development on our part primarily
column9: the cruise missiles; cruise missiles that could be launched from land-based mobile installations; cruise missiles that could be launched - launched from high-performance aircraft
column10: like the B-52s or the B-1s
column11: which I hope we proceed with; cruise missiles which could be launched from either surface or submarine uh - naval vessels. Those gray-area weapons systems are creating some problems in a - the agreement for a SALT II negotiation. But I can say that I am dedicated to proceeding
column12: and I met just last week with the foreign minister of the Soviet Union
column13: and he indicated to me that uh - the Soviet Union was interested in narrowing the differences and making a realistic and a sound compromise. I hope and trust
column14: in the best interest of both countries
column15: and in the best interests of all people throughout this globe
column16: that the Soviet Union and the United States can make a mutually beneficial agreement. Because if we do not and SALT I expires on October three
column18: you will unleash again an all-out nuclear arms race with the potential of a nuclear holocaust of unbelievable dimensions. So it's the obligation of the president to do just that
column19: and I intend to do so.

column1: I believe that the cruise missiles which we are now developing in research and development across the spectrum from air
column3: or from the land
column4: uh - can be uh - included within a SALT II agreement. They are a new weapons system that has a great potential
column5: both conventional and nuclear armed. At the same time
column6: we have to make certain that the Soviet Union's Backfire
column7: which they claim is not an intercontinental aircraft and which some of our people contend is
column8: must also be included if we are to get the kind of agreement which is in the best interest of both countries. And I really believe that it - it's far better for us and for the Soviet Union
column9: and more importantly for the people around the world
column10: that these two superpowers find an answer for a SALT II agreement before October three
column11: 1977. I think good will on both parts
column12: hard bargaining by both parties and a reasonable compromise will be in the best interests of all parties.

column1: Well
column2: Mr. Ford acts like he's uh - running for president for the first time. He's been in office two years
column3: and there has been absolutely no progress made toward a new SALT agreement. He has learned the date of the expiration of SALT I
column4: apparently. We've seen
column5: in this world
column6: a development of a tremendous threat to us. As a nuclear engineer myself
column7: I know the limitations and capabilities of atomic power. I also - know that as far as the human beings on this earth are concerned that the nonproliferation of atomic weapons is number one. Only the last few days with the election approaching
column8: has Mr. Ford taken any interest in a nonproliferation movement. I advocated last May in a speech at the United Nations that we move immediately as a nation to declare a complete moratorium on the testing of all nuclear devices
column9: both weapons and peaceful devices; that we not ship any more atomic fuel to a country that refuses to comply with strict controls over the waste which can be reprocessed into explosives. I've also advocated that we stop the sale by Germany and France of - processing plants for Pakistan and Brazil. Mr. Ford hasn't moved on this. We also need to provide an adequate supply of enriched uranium. Mr. Ford
column10: again
column11: under pressure from the atomic energy lobby
column12: has insisted that this reprocessing or rather re-en- enrichment be done by private industry and not by the existing uh - government uh - plants. This kind of confusion and absence of leadership has let us drift now for two years with a constantly increasing threat of atomic weapons throughout the world. We now have five nations that have atomic bombs that we know about. If we continue under Mr. Ford's policy by 1985 or '90 we'll have twenty nations that have the capability of exploding atomic weapons. This has got to be stopped. That is one of the major challenges and major undertakings that I will assume as the next president.

column3: 8)	" First we have to understand that SALT I expires October third 1977. Uh - Mr. Brezhnev and I met in Vladivostok in December of 1974 for the purpose of trying to take the initial step so we could have a SALT II agreement that would go to l985. As I indicated earlier
column4: we did agree on a twenty-four-hundred limitation on uh - uh - launchers of ballistic missiles. Uh - that would mean a cutback in the Soviet program; it would not interfere with our own program. At the same time
column5: we put a limitation of thirteen hundred and twenty on MIRVs. Our technicians have been working since that time in Geneva
column6: trying to put into technical language a - an agreement that can be verified by both parties. In the meantime
column7: there has developed the problem of the Soviet Backfire - their high-performance aircraft which they say is not a long-range aircraft and which some of our people say is a intercontinental aircraft. In the interim
column8: there has been the development on our part primarily
column9: the cruise missiles; cruise missiles that could be launched from land-based mobile installations; cruise missiles that could be launched - launched from high-performance aircraft
column10: like the B-52s or the B-1s
column11: which I hope we proceed with; cruise missiles which could be launched from either surface or submarine uh - naval vessels. Those gray-area weapons systems are creating some problems in a - the agreement for a SALT II negotiation. But I can say that I am dedicated to proceeding
column12: and I met just last week with the foreign minister of the Soviet Union
column13: and he indicated to me that uh - the Soviet Union was interested in narrowing the differences and making a realistic and a sound compromise. I hope and trust
column14: in the best interest of both countries
column15: and in the best interests of all people throughout this globe
column16: that the Soviet Union and the United States can make a mutually beneficial agreement. Because if we do not and SALT I expires on October three
column18: you will unleash again an all-out nuclear arms race with the potential of a nuclear holocaust of unbelievable dimensions. So it's the obligation of the president to do just that
column19: and I intend to do so.

column1: I believe that the cruise missiles which we are now developing in research and development across the spectrum from air
column3: or from the land
column4: uh - can be uh - included within a SALT II agreement. They are a new weapons system that has a great potential
column5: both conventional and nuclear armed. At the same time
column6: we have to make certain that the Soviet Union's Backfire
column7: which they claim is not an intercontinental aircraft and which some of our people contend is
column8: must also be included if we are to get the kind of agreement which is in the best interest of both countries. And I really believe that it - it's far better for us and for the Soviet Union
column9: and more importantly for the people around the world
column10: that these two superpowers find an answer for a SALT II agreement before October three
column11: 1977. I think good will on both parts
column12: hard bargaining by both parties and a reasonable compromise will be in the best interests of all parties.

column1: Well
column2: Mr. Ford acts like he's uh - running for president for the first time. He's been in office two years
column3: and there has been absolutely no progress made toward a new SALT agreement. He has learned the date of the expiration of SALT I
column4: apparently. We've seen
column5: in this world
column6: a development of a tremendous threat to us. As a nuclear engineer myself
column7: I know the limitations and capabilities of atomic power. I also - know that as far as the human beings on this earth are concerned that the nonproliferation of atomic weapons is number one. Only the last few days with the election approaching
column8: has Mr. Ford taken any interest in a nonproliferation movement. I advocated last May in a speech at the United Nations that we move immediately as a nation to declare a complete moratorium on the testing of all nuclear devices
column9: both weapons and peaceful devices; that we not ship any more atomic fuel to a country that refuses to comply with strict controls over the waste which can be reprocessed into explosives. I've also advocated that we stop the sale by Germany and France of - processing plants for Pakistan and Brazil. Mr. Ford hasn't moved on this. We also need to provide an adequate supply of enriched uranium. Mr. Ford
column10: again
column11: under pressure from the atomic energy lobby
column12: has insisted that this reprocessing or rather re-en- enrichment be done by private industry and not by the existing uh - government uh - plants. This kind of confusion and absence of leadership has let us drift now for two years with a constantly increasing threat of atomic weapons throughout the world. We now have five nations that have atomic bombs that we know about. If we continue under Mr. Ford's policy by 1985 or '90 we'll have twenty nations that have the capability of exploding atomic weapons. This has got to be stopped. That is one of the major challenges and major undertakings that I will assume as the next president.

column3: 9)	" No
column4: it's not just campaign rhetoric. I think that militarily we are as strong as any nation on earth. I think we got to stay that way and continue to increase our capabilities to meet any potential threat. But as far as strength derived from commitment to principles
column5: as far as strength derived from the unity within our country
column6: as far as strength derived from the people
column7: the Congress
column8: the secretary of state
column9: the president
column10: sharing in the evolution and carrying-out of a foreign policy
column11: as far as strength derived from the respect of our own allies and friends
column12: their assurance that we will be staunch in our commitment
column13: that we will not deviate and that we'll give them adequate attention
column14: as far as - as strength derived from doing what's right - caring for the poor
column15: providing food
column16: becoming the breadbasket of the world instead of the arms merchant of the world - in those respects
column17: we're not strong. Also
column18: we'll never be strong again overseas
column19: unless we're strong at home. And with our economy in such terrible disarray and getting worse by the month. We've got five-hundred thousand more Americans unemployed today than we had three months ago. We've got two and a half million more Americans out of work now than we had when Mr. Ford took office. This kind of deterioration in our economic strength is bound to weaken us around the world. And we not only have uh problems at home but we export those problems overseas. So as far as the respect of our own people toward our own government
column20: as far as participating in the shaping of uh - concepts and commitments
column21: as far as the trust of our country among the nations of the world
column22: as far as dependence of our country in meeting the needs and obligations that we've expressed to our allies
column23: as far as the respect of our country - even among our potential adversaries - we are weak. Potentially we're strong. Under this administration that strength has not been realized.

column1: Governor Carter uh - brags about the unemployment during Democratic administrations and condemns the unemployment at the present time. I must remind him that we're at peace and during the period that he brags about unemployment being low
column2: the United States was at war. Now let me correct one other comment that uh - Governor Carter has made. I have recommended to the Congress that we develop the uranium enrichment plant at Portsmouth
column3: Ohio
column4: which is a publicly owned - U.S. government facility and have indicated that the private program which would follow on in Alabama is one that may or may not uhh - be constructed. But I am committed to the one at Portsmouth
column5: Ohio. The governor also talks about morality in foreign policy. The foreign policy of the United States meets the highest standards of morality. What is more moral than peace
column6: and the United States is at peace today? What is more moral in foreign policy than for the administration to take the lead in the World Food Conference in Rome in 1974 when the United States committed six million metric tons of food - over 60 percent of the food committed for the disadvantaged and underdeveloped nations of the world? The Ford administration wants to eradicate hunger and disease in our underdeveloped countries throughout the world. What is more moral than for the United States under the Ford administration to take the lead in southern Africa

column5: as far as strength derived from the unity within our country
column6: as far as strength derived from the people
column7: the Congress
column8: the secretary of state
column9: the president
column10: sharing in the evolution and carrying-out of a foreign policy

column13: that we will not deviate and that we'll give them adequate attention
column14: as far as - as strength derived from doing what's right - caring for the poor
column15: providing food
column16: becoming the breadbasket of the world instead of the arms merchant of the world - in those respects
column17: we're not strong. Also
column18: we'll never be strong again overseas
column19: unless we're strong at home. And with our economy in such terrible disarray and getting worse by the month. We've got five-hundred thousand more Americans unemployed today than we had three months ago. We've got two and a half million more Americans out of work now than we had when Mr. Ford took office. This kind of deterioration in our economic strength is bound to weaken us around the world. And we not only have uh problems at home but we export those problems overseas. So as far as the respect of our own people toward our own government
column20: as far as participating in the shaping of uh - concepts and commitments
column21: as far as the trust of our country among the nations of the world

column1: Governor Carter uh - brags about the unemployment during Democratic administrations and condemns the unemployment at the present time. I must remind him that we're at peace and during the period that he brags about unemployment being low
column2: the United States was at war. Now let me correct one other comment that uh - Governor Carter has made. I have recommended to the Congress that we develop the uranium enrichment plant at Portsmouth
column3: Ohio
column4: which is a publicly owned - U.S. government facility and have indicated that the private program which would follow on in Alabama is one that may or may not uhh - be constructed. But I am committed to the one at Portsmouth
column5: Ohio. The governor also talks about morality in foreign policy. The foreign policy of the United States meets the highest standards of morality. What is more moral than peace
column6: and the United States is at peace today? What is more moral in foreign policy than for the administration to take the lead in the World Food Conference in Rome in 1974 when the United States committed six million metric tons of food - over 60 percent of the food committed for the disadvantaged and underdeveloped nations of the world? The Ford administration wants to eradicate hunger and disease in our underdeveloped countries throughout the world. What is more moral than for the United States under the Ford administration to take the lead in southern Africa
column7: in the Middle East? Those are initiatives in foreign policy which are of the highest moral standard and that is indicative of the foreign policy of this country.

column3: 9)	" No
column4: it's not just campaign rhetoric. I think that militarily we are as strong as any nation on earth. I think we got to stay that way and continue to increase our capabilities to meet any potential threat. But as far as strength derived from commitment to principles
column5: as far as strength derived from the unity within our country
column6: as far as strength derived from the people
column7: the Congress
column8: the secretary of state
column9: the president
column10: sharing in the evolution and carrying-out of a foreign policy
column11: as far as strength derived from the respect of our own allies and friends
column12: their assurance that we will be staunch in our commitment
column13: that we will not deviate and that we'll give them adequate attention
column14: as far as - as strength derived from doing what's right - caring for the poor
column15: providing food
column16: becoming the breadbasket of the world instead of the arms merchant of the world - in those respects
column17: we're not strong. Also
column18: we'll never be strong again overseas
column19: unless we're strong at home. And with our economy in such terrible disarray and getting worse by the month. We've got five-hundred thousand more Americans unemployed today than we had three months ago. We've got two and a half million more Americans out of work now than we had when Mr. Ford took office. This kind of deterioration in our economic strength is bound to weaken us around the world. And we not only have uh problems at home but we export those problems overseas. So as far as the respect of our own people toward our own government
column20: as far as participating in the shaping of uh - concepts and commitments
column21: as far as the trust of our country among the nations of the world
column22: as far as dependence of our country in meeting the needs and obligations that we've expressed to our allies
column23: as far as the respect of our country - even among our potential adversaries - we are weak. Potentially we're strong. Under this administration that strength has not been realized.

column1: Governor Carter uh - brags about the unemployment during Democratic administrations and condemns the unemployment at the present time. I must remind him that we're at peace and during the period that he brags about unemployment being low
column2: the United States was at war. Now let me correct one other comment that uh - Governor Carter has made. I have recommended to the Congress that we develop the uranium enrichment plant at Portsmouth
column3: Ohio
column4: which is a publicly owned - U.S. government facility and have indicated that the private program which would follow on in Alabama is one that may or may not uhh - be constructed. But I am committed to the one at Portsmouth
column5: Ohio. The governor also talks about morality in foreign policy. The foreign policy of the United States meets the highest standards of morality. What is more moral than peace
column6: and the United States is at peace today? What is more moral in foreign policy than for the administration to take the lead in the World Food Conference in Rome in 1974 when the United States committed six million metric tons of food - over 60 percent of the food committed for the disadvantaged and underdeveloped nations of the world? The Ford administration wants to eradicate hunger and disease in our underdeveloped countries throughout the world. What is more moral than for the United States under the Ford administration to take the lead in southern Africa
column7: in the Middle East? Those are initiatives in foreign policy which are of the highest moral standard and that is indicative of the foreign policy of this country.
